EXTRACT from Report of Separate School Inspector Greening, dated May 7th, 1931, on his inspection of the KABONI INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

Original on File 19-2-6.

The furnace smokes badly. When I was at the school, I went to look at the furnace, and discovered that the smoke stack has a complete "U" turn in it. This no doubt accounts for the smoking. I should say that the position of the furnace was not very carefully planned.

One of the locks on the door does not work and an ordinary hook and eyelet are used. This arrangement is far from ornamental.
Ottawa, June 30, 1931.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his visit to the Kaboni Indian Day School in May, last, draws attention to the condition of the furnace. He states that it smokes badly, owing to the smoke stack having a complete "U" turn in it, which, no doubt, accounts for the smoking. He also states that one of the locks on the door does not work and an ordinary hook and eyelet are used, and that this arrangement is far from ornamental.

I have to request that you will make an examination of the smoke stack of the furnace, with a view to improving its condition and placing same in good order. Could not this smoke stack be straightened and a good draft obtained, in order to carry off the smoke. You should furnish a report regarding this matter, stating what you would recommend be done to overcome the present difficulty.

You should also arrange to have the lock on the door referred to by the Inspector repaired, or a new lock installed.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning, Ont.

Form No. 101
Sir:-

I am in receipt of Departmental Letter No. 19-2-5 of the 30th ultimo with reference to the report made by the Separate School Inspector regarding the condition of the furnace in the Kaboni Day School, and in reply I have the honour to report that this morning a mechanic and myself paid a visit to this school and made a thorough examination of this furnace and found that all the dampers which control the drafts had been kept closed, loaded with ashes and left so long in that condition that they are now twisted and will not open. It may be the case that the furnace will have to be taken apart and new dampers installed, but before doing this an effort will be made to have them straightened by means of a blowtorch.

There does not appear to be anything wrong with the smoke stack, and during the past has had plenty of draft, and no doubt but it would have ample draft at the present time if the dampers were made use of properly.

The hook and eyelet which locks the door on the entrance to the cellar way will be taken off and a new lock installed.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Indian Agent,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

EXTRACT from Report of Mr. Indian Agent Lewis regarding the KABONI INDIAN DAY SCHOOL - for the Month of November, 1932. - Original on File 19-2-7.

The school building should have the storm windows installed before the cold weather sets in, and there are five broken glass in the basement windows which should be replaced; also a supply of fuel split and piled in the basement for winter use; the total cost of having everything put in shape at this school should not exceed $10.00.

I might also say that on account of so many pupils attending this school live at long distances, it would be advisable that hot cocoa be served with their lunch at midday, the cost would not exceed $4.00 a month.
Ottawa, November 23, 1932.

Sir:

With reference to your report for the current month on the Kaboni Indian Day School, I have to say that you may arrange to have the storm windows installed, the five broken panes of glass in the basement windows replaced and the supply of fuel for the winter's use split and piled in the basement. It is noted you estimate the total cost of the above work should not exceed $10. After this work has been carried out, you should forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Regarding the furnishing of supplies for a hot drink to the pupils at midday, I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase of a quantity of cocoa, sugar, etc., to an amount not exceeding the sum of $4 per month during the period from December first, next, to the end of April following. You should obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate. These are to be attached to proper voucher forms, certified in the usual manner and forwarded for payment from time to time, as the purchase of supplies for the hot drink is made.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning, Ont.

Byrne requesting permission to secure a garage at her own expense at the Kaboni Indian Day School, and that a small shed from the old Wikwemikong School could be removed to the Kaboni School; I have the honour to report that there is a small building at the old Wikwemikong School which was in use as a woodshed. As this school has been closed for a number of years past and not likely to re-open again and for that reason the shed would be of no further use where it is at present so I would recommend that Miss Byrne be granted permission to have it moved to the Kaboni School at her own expense.

Sir:

I have the honour to report to the effect that the furnace which has been in use for the purpose of heating the classroom and teacher's residence at the Kaboni Indian Day School is in a state of very bad repair.

It has been in use since the school building was erected twenty years ago, and has given satisfactory service in heating the building until the last winter past. It is now burned inside to such an extent that it is cracked and twisted and through these cracks the smoke escapes into the hot air pipes and fills the whole building with smoke. I had the firebox repaired and the cracks filled with furnace putty in order that it could be made use of until the warm weather set in, but it is again in a bad state of repair. On examining it recently I found that it is past further usefulness and should be replaced by a new furnace before such time as it will be needed to heat the building during the incoming fall.

I asked a dealer in furnaces etc as to the probable cost of installing a suitable furnace similar to the one which has been in use, and he advised me that the approx. cost would amount to $125.00.

I have to report also that the ceilings and interior walls of the classroom and teachers' residence of this building are now in a dismal condition and should be renovated with two coats of muresco, also the woodwork should have a coat of oil, the cost of having this work carried out will not exceed $50.00.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:-

With regard to my letter to the Department dated July 24th last, in reference to a new furnace for the Kaboni Indian School of which the probable cost would amount to $125.00, and the Department authorized an expenditure of $130.00 for this purpose by E.R.No.3466; I have the honour to report that the old furnace has been removed in order to have everything ready to install a new furnace, and now I find that a large suitable furnace for this school, without casing, will cost $228.00 net, delivered on Manitowaning wharf, or one not quite so large delivered in Manitowaning $205.00, but the large one would be the most suitable for the Kaboni Indian School and residence. There would be an extra expense in transportation of the furnace from Manitowaning to Kaboni School and labour re-building the brick casing around the furnace, the cost will amount to at least $15.00.

The standard of a furnace which has been in use during the past is not made by the firm now, and the dealer who advised me as the approx. cost of a similar furnace to the one which has been in use at $125.00 made a error in his quotation to the amount of $100.00.

As it is necessary to have a new furnace installed in this school immediately on account of the cold weather being liable to set in at any time now, I would recommend that authority be granted to install the large furnace at a cost of $228.00 delivered in Manitowaning, and a cost of $75.00 for transportation from Manitowaning and labour in having it installed in the basement of the school building.

Your obedient servant,

Manitowaning, April 10th, 1937

Sir:

I enclose herewith a voucher in my favour, with receipts attached, showing payments for labour and material in repairs to Kaboni School building, and also repairs to the water well pump in use at this school.

It was necessary to have these repairs carried out without delay as the roof of this building was in a bad state of repair on account of being damaged by fire, and had to be given attention before any wet weather would set in.

On the 23rd of the last month past, a fire broke out on the roof of this building during school hours. Through good work of the teacher, pupils and a few Indian neighbours living close to the school, they were able to extinguish the fire before much damage was done. Approx. ten feet square was destroyed to such an extent that it had to be replaced by new material, but it was given attention immediately and now it is in a state of good repair. During the excitement among the members working at the fire the handle bearer of the well pump was broken and had to be replaced by a new one.

The cause of this fire is not known as the chimney is a brick structure with the flue lined with glazed tile and is in first class condition. It is thought that a live spark from the chimney fell on the dry cedar shingles as there is not any other way this fire could have started.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

I could not help noticing what an improvement the interior painting of the school had made, but the pupils' entrances need repairing. I should imagine that, in their present state, they are more or less dangerous.

The blackboards at this school have been ruined by having been painted over with some kind of surface-coating. It is quite difficult to write anything upon them that can be read legibly from the back of the room. I do not know what can be done with them, however, unless they are gone over with sandpaper.

(Sgd.) W. J. Greening,
Inspector of Schools.
Dear Sir:

The Department has just received a report regarding an inspection of the Kaboni Indian Day School by Inspector Greening. In this report he states that the pupils' entrances need repairing. If this matter has not received attention since the date of the Inspector's visit you should have these entrances repaired immediately.

The Inspector also states that the blackboards are in very bad condition and suggests that they be sandpapered and then re-painted. If you consider this would improve them you may arrange for this work.

Yours truly,

Sir:

I wish to report, the Kaboni Indian Day School is badly in need of painting as it is about 10 years since it was last painted.

The building is approximately 45 ft square and it should have at least two coats, and the loose siding should be nailed tightly before the paint is applied.

It would require about 10 gallons of paint which can be purchased locally at $4.00 per gallon. Oil, brushes and nails would cost approximately $5.00 and it would take about 13 ten hour days labour at $3.00 per day to complete the whole job, making a total cost of $84.00. The work can be done with Indian labour.

Fresh paint will serve to keep the building from deteriorating; therefore, I would recommend authority be granted to have this work carried out immediately.

August 26, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 16th instant in which you submit, for Departmental consideration, the desirability of repairing the Kaboni Indian day school.

I regret to state that the funds at our disposal will not enable us to proceed with the painting of this school during the present fiscal year. It might be advisable, however, to have the loose siding to which you refer renailed. You should renew your request for the paint necessary at this school in your next year's estimates.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,

June 6, 1942

Sir:

I enclose herewith requisition for material to renovate and decorate Indian Day School's class room and living quarters.

The walls and ceilings have formerly been done with muresco, and are very dingy and smoky. I strongly disapprove of muresco, as it cannot be washed without a great deal of work, and must have a fresh application each time it is washed, while if the walls were painted, they can be readily washed and kept clean at all times.

The cost of the labour involved to renovate and redecorate is estimated at $85.00.

There is also a part of the basement from which the earth was never removed. The space is required for storing fuel, and the earth could be used to level a small swampy place at the rear of the school grounds, which breeds mosquitos. It is estimated this would cost approximately $75.00, and I would be pleased to receive an advance cheque for $160.00 to pay wages for this work, if the material can be supplied.

For convenience, I would recommend the material be purchased locally from C. W. Hinds.

Yours very truly,

November 19, 1942

Sir:

I wish to make a report on the furnace at Kaboni Indian Day School.

Quite a large hole is burned through the top part of the fire box, which renders the furnace unsafe, and allows smoke to enter the class room through the hot air registers.

I have had John King, the Indian plumber and tinsmith, put a patch on, which he says is only temporary, and may give out at any time, so I would advise getting a new part for the top half of fire box so it could be replaced on short notice.

Mr. C. W. Hinds of Manitowaning quotes a price of $61.00 I think for this, and there would be some freight charges, bolts, furnace cement, and labour to install, which would bring the total to approximately $75.00.

I would like to get this authorized before navigation closes on the lakes, if possible, which would lower the cost of freight and cartage.

Yours very truly,

August 10, 1944.

Mr. C.R. Johnston, Indian Agent, Manitowaning, Ont.

I have your letter of the 7th instant, enclosing requisition for articles required at the Kaboni School. The Department approves the purchase of the articles shown on the attached requisition, with the exception of the expenditure for manual training supplies.

It is noted that for each of the schools in your agency you request a grant for manual training supplies for both boys and girls. While we are anxious to encourage the activity programme in manual training at all schools, we wish to be certain, before authorizing an expenditure, that the teacher concerned is capable of giving instruction in manual training to the boys and in sewing, knitting etc. to the girls. Please let me have a general report regarding the schools in your agency in this regard. I realize the amounts involved at each school are small, but at the same time there is no use in furnishing materials if the teacher is not sufficiently competent to carry out a proper programme.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

I wish to report a few repairs are required at Kaboni School.

Some windows were broken Halloween night, and an attempt by the police to locate the culprits has been unsuccessful.

The door at outside entrance to basement went to pieces, and had to be replaced with a new door and door frame. This has been repaired already at a cost of $4.00 for labour, and $.47 for lumber, which was procured from L. A. Buck of Little Current.

A new lock is required on one class room door, and would advise a heavy thumb latch and night latch, as ordinary locks do not give satisfaction due to frost action at this corner of the building.

The platforms at classroom entrances, and the toilets also require some repairs, which together with replacing broken windows will cost about $20.00 for labour.

I would be pleased to have authority for these repairs at your earliest convenience.

A requisition for material is enclosed, and with exception of the lumber, the prices are quoted by C. W. Hinds of Manitowaning.

C. R. Johnston,
Indian Agent

Memorandum:

Inspection of Kaboni Indian Day School.

- TEACHER -

Miss Leblanc has an Elementary Certificate from the Province of Quebec. She has had twenty-two years Provincial teaching experience and six years in Indian Schools. Her teaching methods are rather old fashioned but she certainly believes in keeping the children busy and well occupied throughout the entire school day. As a result she has brought some of these children along very well. Encouraging results can be anticipated. Her children tested quite well and I think we should retain the services of this teacher.

- TEACHERAGE -

This building is fairly good but faces the wrong way. As a result the six windows are somewhat wasted and the room is dark. The teacher's quarters are quite good although a little old. Apparently the school was built about 1914. There is a very good furnace and the entire building is warm enough the year round. This furnace was installed in 1924. The big difficulty here is the lack of water. The well is dry and the water has to be brought from several hundred yards away. The matter of drilling a well is one that will have to be considered. A new roof will also have to be provided in two or three years. In ordering shingles for the other schools, we are using the same shade and type so that extra shingles can be sent to Kaboni for use next summer. This school should serve us for a few more years yet.

Bernard F. Neary,
BFM/HM.
Supt. of Indian Education.

Kaboni Indian Day School.

You will recall our discussion with regard to the water supply at this school. It would seem evident that we are always going to have difficulty in securing a teacher for this school until we provide for an adequate source of water.

Therefore I would appreciate your having the well digger employed for the Lakeview School give us a report regarding the possibility of digging another well at or near the Kaboni School. In this way a decision can be reached as to the possible cost of providing a water supply.

Bernard F. Neary,

Re: Kaboni Indian Day School

I wish to acknowledge receipt of Department Letter No. 19-2-5 dated May 28, 1948 with reference to the water supply at Kaboni School.

Mr. Richard McMullen, who is drilling for water at Lakeview School, advises me he drilled the present well at Kaboni about thirty years ago and he is satisfied that with the kind of rock found at this particular location, that usable water would not be obtained by drilling.

Since good water was obtained just a few rods from the school by digging, I would suggest we might try digging close to the school although the well across the road is said to go dry for a while during the dry seasons but would in all probability give us an ample supply of water for seven or eight months of the year.

C. R. Johnston,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency.

Re: Kaboni Indian Day School

With further reference to obtaining a water supply at the above school, I have located three Indians who will undertake the work at .60¢ per hour, $1.00 per hour for man and team.

From careful study of dug wells in the vicinity, I would judge it will be approximately twelve feet to the rock. The soil is heavy clay and it is considered unlikely that we will locate any particular vein of water in this type of soil. I would consider therefore it is most important to have the well large in diameter as the condensation of moisture from the clay soil during the hot weather will be about the only source of replenishing the water supply.

It is difficult to estimate just what the cost will be but the Indians demand payment at least once a week. In this type of soil and for a well of large diameter, I would suggest the customary stone cribbing as most satisfactory and a cedar platform over the top.

I would suggest $200.00 as a maximum figure and would be pleased to have an advance as early as possible.

During Mr. Neary's visit to the Agency in May, it was agreed I believe, to have the classroom ceiling repainted and a wall-board of some kind
installed on one room in living quarters. Miss Leblanc mentioned ten-test which I find difficult to secure here and would suggest Gyproc as superior to ten-test or Insul board and can be obtained locally from C.W. Hinds.

The materials have been included on a requisition already submitted and I would estimate $125.00 for labour on this work which may be included with advance to dig the well.

C. R. Johnston,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency.

I acknowledge receipt of Department letter No. 19-2-5 (E.1) with reference to requisition prepared by Miss Edith Leblanc for Kaboni School.

I realize this was quite a large requisition but I have always attempted to discourage frequent requisitions and Miss Leblanc has made a careful study of her requirements for several months.

It is considered there are very few, if any, articles listed on the requisition that should be supplied by the teacher and it is not understood what is meant by not supplying materials that may be considered expendable. It has always been customary to supply the necessary dishes and cutlery for teacher's residence; mops, brooms, cleaning materials and tea towelling for the classroom. It is noted that Miss Leblanc did not specify the tea towelling was for classroom use during the winter when hot lunch is served.

It is also noted that wick and chimneys for Aladdin Lamp are allowed but not the mantles.

A mouse proof flour bin is urgently needed and the galvanized container intended for garbage is the only thing available locally that would serve the purpose.

Miss Leblanc will also be very disappointed at not receiving the usual allotment for manual training.
I was under the impression the Department wished to encourage the teaching of Manual Training in their schools and I am sure the omission must be an oversight.

I would therefore respectfully request that this requisition be reviewed again as there are several articles omitted that are most essential and unless there has been a drastic change in policy would not be supplied by the Teacher.

C. R. Johnston,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency.

I wish to refer to my letter dated July 22, 1948 with reference to digging a well and making some other repairs at Kaboni School.

The cost of the well was estimated at $200.00 and other repairs at $125.00. An advance cheque for $125.00 was received and applied on digging the well which is now completed with the exception of a covering and installation of pump. It would probably be advisable to have a concrete covering over the stone cribbing.

The well is costing more than was anticipated as it was considered we would strike rock at ten or twelve feet. The digging was very hard for the first ten feet and we did not contact rock until a depth of seventeen feet.

The cost of labour on the well to date is $253.20 and will cost probably fifty dollars more to complete the covering in addition to the pump.

I would therefore be pleased to have a further advance of $200.00 to complete the well and proceed with renovating interior of the school at the earliest convenience.

C. H. Johnston,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency.

Extract from Regional Supervisor Matters' report dated July 13th.

KABONI

This school was closed, the teacher having taken the pupils on a picnic. Apparently, they had kept school open June 6th to make up for this. Possibly a good idea but one that should have been sanctioned by the local Superintendent.

A walk consisting of large flat stones had been laid from the gate to the entrance. It was very rough and I would consider it dangerous. It would be preferrable to raise the walk out of the surrounding clay with either crushed stone or cement.

A number of minor repairs and painting are required. This will be covered by Mr. Johnston.

We intend fill up the spaces with cement to make a real nice walk. While we were away on a picnic in June, Mr. Montour and a Dept. man came to the school. I know how to prepare the cement and shall teach the children to do so if you let me do it. It is such a muddy place around the school in the spring and in the fall, I thought this walk could help keep the floor cleaner.

Dear Miss Leblanc:

I have for answer your letter of October 1st and wish to advise that the Department is painting all the dark brown woodwork in its day schools a light green or buff colour.

This is being done on the advice of lighting officials who claim that this dark brown colour in the classroom has a darkening effect.

Mr. Matters has spoken to me with regard to the walk which you have placed leading to the school steps. The main point is that this walk must not be dangerous to the children. If you are careful in setting these stones evenly in cement then we are prepared to have the walk laid.

In reply to your letter of 14th inst., No. 152579, requesting me to report on the remarks of Miss Little, school teacher at Kettle St. Reserve, I might say that Miss Little is talking about something that she knows nothing about.

The Hon:
The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs:

MEMORANDUM re Kettle Point School:

The undersigned begs to submit the following report on the above mentioned school in charge of Miss E.J. Little:

Miss Little has been teaching at Kettle Point, in the northerly part of the County of Lambton on Lake Huron for the past two years and is paid a salary of $250 per annum from the funds of the Band. She is 33 years old and only holds a High School Entrance Certificate. Mr Public School Inspector Barnes visits this school semi-annually and his last report is sent herewith. In a prior report the Inspector says that the teacher is doing as well as he could expect her to. All the pupils of school age, -17- are enrolled and the average attendance for last year was 12.

The teacher attributes the want of greater progress to the lack of punctuality on the part of pupils.

No previous complaints have been received regarding this teacher, who is reported by the Inspector to be "fairly satisfactory in her work as a teacher".

Sir: Please find enclosed the quarterly report of the Kettle Point school for the quarter ending on Friday last. I have very little comment to make further than to explain why the school was only open for nineteen days. There would under ordinary circumstances have been two weeks in August and about 2 days in September but for the holiday season while I was up at Stony Point trying to get the foundation of the School house there ready for it to open at the right time. I watched on the case of small pox at Stony Point and immediately took steps to have it stamped out. Amongst precautions taken was the vaccination of all unvaccinated persons and all the school children were vaccinated and just when the school should have been opened they were laid up and the doctor said they were in an unfit condition to attend school so the council and myself and Doctor Patterson decided to let the school remain closed until the children were fit to attend. Besides this at first there was great excitement in the neighborhood especially at Upperwood Beach between Kettle Point and Stony Point where Dr. A.B. McCallum Principal Walter of Our College and a number of other London people with ministers of different churches were holidaying. In summer time it is quite a large village then) something had to be done to restore confidence and the fact that the schools were closed and the infected houses quarantined with a constable on guard and general vaccination enforced soon quieted things. At first Dr. McCallum and others wanted the two reserves quarantined also and all Indians penned in on their reserves but things are now in their normal condition and the schools are going on and the Inspector I think has made his visit. I also enclose a requisition for supplies from Mrs. George.

Finding this is satisfactory I remain

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I am enclosing herewith quarterly report of the Kettle Point school made out by Mrs. McKinnon and am sorry indeed to have to say that the conduct of Mr. McKinnon was such as to force his wife to give up her work at Kettle Point and the school is, therefore, now without a teacher.

I saw Mr. McKinnon at the time his wife was engaged to take the school and he seemed quite satisfied that she should do so. She made provisions for him by arranging that he should take his meals at a house near their home and he would sleep at home but she had scarcely left town before he went off and got drunk. She came down on Saturday last to see how things were going to find him in the house in a drunken stupor. The neighbours report that he had had other drunken fellow in with him.

She of course was greatly exercised over the matter and came to the office and I scarcely knew what to say but was forced to admit that if he was going to act in this manner that I could not press her to carry out her agreement to teach the school. However, she returned to Kettle Point on Sunday morning early and in the afternoon who should put in an appearance but McKinnon and he simply stayed around the place refusing to come away without her.

He certainly has acted the part of an imbecile but there seems to be no remedy except for her to remain at home. She seems to have a very good control over him and he works well excepting when he takes drink but he very seldom does when she is around. The doctor holds out no encouragement to expect Mrs. George to take up her duties again before the first of next year and I do not know where to find a teacher.
The only one available is Edwin Menass. He applied you will remember at the time Miss Weaver did for the Stony Point school. Miss Weaver was given the preference.

Ed is a very nice lad and I am sure will do the very best he can but one difficulty is that he is without experience but I think it would be far better to have him undertake the work than to close the school entirely for the balance of the year. I will await your instructions. If you think well to have Menass go out please telegraph me so that he can commence on Monday next. Mrs. McKinnon was at some expense and put in some time which I think she should be settled with for as she is not really to blame for results and feels very badly over the condition of things growing out of the conduct of her husband.

I will send a statement in the near future.

Your obedient servant,
R. G. Palmer,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

Not being at my office I cannot refer to folio and date but trust you will have no difficulty in tracing the matter to which I am about to refer.

On reaching home from the hospital I was surprised to be informed that Edwin Menass who had been appointed to teach the school at Kettle Point on account of Mrs. George's illness, had not taught some two or three weeks and without intimating to me his dissatisfaction or his intention to give up, closed the school and went home. I cannot understand his conduct. My informant tells me that he thought it was something about the salary. I remember writing him as per your instructions, that his salary would be $300 not $360 as Mrs. George was receiving. It would appear that on receipt of this letter or very soon afterwards he gave up the school. Had he reported to me his dissatisfaction with the salary I certainly would have communicated with the Department and no doubt the little difference would have been paid rather than have the school closed. He has not yet come to me and I don't know when I will see him.

I am, therefore, unable to send in any report; in fact a report for the quarter ending Dec. 31st would be almost a blank.

His conduct is such that he is really undeserving of any payment for the time he did serve, however one can scarcely deal with these Indians as they would with white people; they seem to be so strange in their make-up. You will decide this matter and instruct me in the same.

Mrs. George is getting along nicely and expects to take up her work at the beginning of the year.

Sir,

As a result of the inquiries made by Mr. MacKenzie of this Department into the suggested amalgamation of the Kettle Point and Stony Point Schools I beg to say that the Department does not consider that this would be practicable owing to the distance and want of suitable school accommodation. It has, therefore, been decided to continue both these schools and the services of the present teachers will be retained for the present.

I have to request that you will be good enough to inform the parents that they must send their children regularly to school or otherwise the Department will have to resort to the enforcement of the Regulations, which provide for the commitment to industrial schools of children who fail to take advantage of the day schools in their vicinity.

There are 43 pupils of school age on this reserve. The average attendance since January is 12. There were five present the day of my visit. The children at this school are more progressive than at the Stoney Point school, but they are not up to the standard according to their ages. This is due to the irregularity of attendance. The teacher, Mrs. George would get good results, if the children would attend more regular.
Ottawa, July 15th, 1916.

Sir,

Mr. R.H. Abraham, recently, visited the Kettle Point day school, and he states that out of an enrolment of 43, there has been, only, an average attendance of 12 since last January.

On August 4th, 1915, you were instructed to inform the parents that they must send their children to school, or, otherwise the regulations would have to be enforced.

Apparently, there has been no improvement in the attendance, and, I have to request that you will at once point out to the Indians that by the Regulations the Department is able to enforce regular attendance at school, and that if they do send their children when the school reopens in the fall, these regulations will be enforced.

At the end of September, you should submit a report on the attendance at this school, so that the Department will be able to judge if the attendance is satisfactory.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of May 15th regarding the resignation of Mrs. Angus George, teacher of the Kettle Point Indian Day School, beg to advise that I have not been able to secure a qualified teacher to fill the vacancy in this school. I have been in communication with Mr. Conn, Public School Inspector, and up to the present time, he does not know of any teacher for this school.

There are two teachers living on the Kettle and Stony Point Reserve who have both taught school, Mrs. Robt. McKinnon, Stony Pt. and John Milliken, Kettle Point (both Indians or half breeds). I was in conversation with John Milliken a short time ago, and he consented to teach the Kettle Point School providing we could not secure a qualified teacher. I believe that he is quite capable and qualified to teach the Kettle Point School, and if no other teacher can be secured I would recommend the appointment of John Milliken until such time as a qualified teacher might be secured.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean, Esq.,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, August 29, 1922.

Sir:-

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 25th instant, informing the Department that you have been unable to secure a qualified teacher to fill the vacancy in the Kettle Point Indian Day School, and recommending that John Milliken be appointed temporarily, until such time as a qualified teacher can be obtained.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of the temporary appointment of John Milliken, to begin duties on September 5th, next, the date on which the schools re-open after the present summer holidays. It is to be distinctly understood that his employment is to be temporary. It is noted that he has had some teaching experience.

The salary allowed Mr. Milliken will be at the rate of $500 per annum, plus bonus provided by law. You may inform him of his temporary appointment and arrange for him to begin duties on the above date. You should, however, keep in mind the necessity of obtaining a qualified teacher and, if possible, one should be secured by the first of October, next.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Dear Sir,

I beg to thank you for your kind letter of the 17th inst., stating "the Department have approved of an increase of my salary of $58.07 a year for teaching at Kettle Point Bay School," and I further beg to thank you and the Department for their kind consideration of this matter.

I am taking this opportunity to bring to your attention the necessity for a new school building at Kettle Point.

The present school house is altogether too small for the number enrolled. The desks are crowded too closely together and it is necessary in some instances to seat three pupils at one double desk. The building itself is old and rather than spend any money on repairs it would be advisable to erect a new school with teacher's residence included.

The parents are taking more interest in sending their children to school and are anxious to have better accommodation.

In this connection it would be as well to give some consideration to a central school for the two reserves. From a casual survey of the situation, I think that this is a matter which Schools Branch should give careful consideration. There are never more than ten or eleven pupils at Stony Point School. This seems to be too few to warrant the expense of upkeep and teacher's salary. The Kettle Point school would be better situated if built up on the hill, near the church. This would bring it much closer to Stony Point reserve and an arrangement could probably be made for transportation of pupils daily to the school and return. I mention this only as a suggestion for consideration and not as a proposition, which has been given careful thought. I do, however, strongly recommend a new school for Kettle Point reserve and that the location be changed to a more central point.
MEMO FOR FILE:

I have discussed with Mr. Inspector Parker and Mr. Mackenzie, both of whom have looked into school matters at Kettle Point and Stony Point, and I believe that the present building at Stony Point should be used as long as there are sufficient pupils available to warrant the activity. At Kettle Point a combined school and residence should be erected at the first opportunity, on a site near the church. The Band Capital Account shows $44,912.08.

Mr. Parker informs me that they will be under heavy expense for roads, etc., during the next few years and he recommends that a Vote of Parliament be secured. I am trying to arrange to have the money provided for the building season of 1925.

We, the undersigned parents and guardians of the Kettle Point day school do hereby request the Indian Agent to place a qualified teacher in our school.

We find that our present teacher Mr. Watt is not the kind of teacher we would like to have teaching our children.

Last spring he sent three of his pupils to the Muncy Institute; he told us that he had them very nearly passing the Entrance Examinations, and that they would pass in three months when they got there. The teachers presented five subjects they had never seen before, and they were longways from passing the entrance. And he told Angus George that he would not undertake to teach children this far advanced in his school, and he does not like to have those same three go back to his school.
If the Indian Dept wishes to know how far advanced those three pupils were advanced they could get the reports at the Institute. At Muncy Oat he told them last Friday that all he would do is to send a telegram to the Indian Dept and they would be taken right back to the Muncy Institute.

Within the last four or five weeks he lets the school about 2 o'clock in the afternoon and goes to work painting the new School. He would rather paint than to perform his duty there are plenty of good painters around here that would be glad to take that work.

Last Friday his pupils told him the people was saying he was making double money by letting the school out early and go painting and he got indignant and he told them what is mentioned above about sending those three back to the Muncy Institute and he knows very well that he cannot do it.

Some of the parents are not sending their children to school because they only get a half day schooling on Fridays.
the younger children say when the older ones are not at school he runs the indian people down as if they were nothing at all, and most of the children say that they can do as they like in school during school hours and he does not make them mind.

He came we had the right to have a qualified in our school as well as any other school again Mr Greenwood tried another school and he got the same answer from the trustees.

Sir:

The Department has, for some time, been giving consideration to the services being performed by Mr. H. D. Watts, teacher of the Kettle Point Indian Day School. It is now considered, in view of his advanced age and in the interests of the Indian children at this school, that a change should be made in the teaching services for the next school year, beginning September 1, 1933. While Mr. Watts has given faithful service, it is thought that the general tone of the school and advancement of the children would be improved if the services of a younger teacher, having the necessary qualifications, were obtained.

I have, therefore, to request that you will inform Mr. Watts that his services will not be required after the end of the present school year, viz., the 30th instant. Mr. Watts should vacate the residence, moving his personal belongings, not later than the middle of August, next, after which time you should make an inventory of the Government property on hand and forward same to the Department. You should see that the school property is well secured until a new teacher arrives.

It will be necessary to obtain a teacher to succeed Mr. Watts, and I would request that you take up the matter with the provincial school inspector with a view to nominating the services of a qualified teacher, one having at least second class professional qualifications. You will be aware as to whether it is preferable to engage a male or female teacher for this school. The name, qualifications and experience of any applicants received by you, with your recommendation, should be submitted to the Department in due time. It is considered, as our funds are limited, that the services of a fully qualified teacher could be obtained at a salary of $80 per teaching month, less the 10 percent during the present fiscal year. MEMORANDUM:

Dr. McGill,

In a letter dated the 23rd instant, Mr. George Dill, teacher of the Kettle Point Indian Day School, requests an increase in salary of $150 a year.

Mr. Dill has a second class Saskatchewan certificate and his first engagement as a teacher of an Indian day school was at Sucker Creek, where he began duties on September 1st, 1931, at a salary of $90 a teaching month. He continued at this school until June 30th, 1933, and was then transferred to the Kettle Point School. At that time, the salary rating at the Kettle Point School was $850 and we could only allow Mr. Dill this amount. He has been in charge of the Kettle Point School since that time and has been paid $85 a teaching month.

The Public School Inspector, Mr. Henry Conn, in reporting on his visit to the Kettle Point School on October 17th, 1935, reported as follows:

"I am unable to point to any place where the management could be materially improved. With an attractive building and grounds, a bright and cheery classroom, superior equipment and a very capable teacher, the children would seem to have every possible inducement to attend regularly."

In view of the favourable report that the Inspector makes regarding the work at this school and the further fact that Mr. Dill's salary was reduced when he transferred from Sucker Creek to Kettle Point, I would recommend that his salary at Kettle Point be increased from April 1st, 1936, from $850 to $900 a year.

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. McGill,

In a letter dated the 23rd instant, Mr. George Dill, teacher of the Kettle Point Indian Day School, requests an increase in salary of $150 a year.

Mr. Dill has a second class Saskatchewan certificate and his first engagement as a teacher of an Indian day school was at Sucker Creek, where he began duties on September 1st, 1931, at a salary of $90 a teaching month. He continued at this school until June 30th, 1933, and was then transferred to the Kettle Point School. At that time, the salary rating at the Kettle Point School was $850 and we could only allow Mr. Dill this amount. He has been in charge of the Kettle Point School since that time and has been paid $85 a teaching month.

The Public School Inspector, Mr. Henry Conn, in reporting on his visit to the Kettle Point School on October 17th, 1935, reported as follows:-

"I am unable to point to any place where the management could be materially improved. With an attractive building and grounds, a bright and cheery classroom, superior equipment and a very capable teacher, the children would seem to have every possible inducement to attend regularly."

In view of the favourable report that the Inspector makes regarding the work at this school and the further fact that Mr. Dill's salary was reduced when he transferred from Sucker Creek to Kettle Point, I would recommend that his salary at Kettle Point be increased from April 1st, 1936, from $850 to $900 a year.

Dear Mr. Sutherland,

Unsolicited I have received invitations for the children of this School to sing as several of the adjacent Fall Fairs in September and October. The Forest Fair Board have offered them a fee of fifteen dollars for three numbers together with a further amount of ten dollars to be divided between this School and the one at Stony Point for competition of Indian School work.

Naturally, my reply was that I should have to consult the department. If there is no objection on your part I should like to complete this arrangement as in this manner I could realize sufficient funds to cover the musical instruction for the Dominion Musical Festival to be held in London in November and continue it through the year in an attempt to successfully defend the County trophy which they already hold.

The parents would, I know, be delighted to have the children do this work and their attitude toward the whole of the musical education has been most stimulating. They have already discussed various means of raising the tuition for next year amongst themselves, but I would prefer this method if possible. The principal thing as I see it is in the broadening of the child's outlook as well as an opportunity to appear before the public.

I shall appreciate your kind consideration of the whole matter.

Yours very truly,

The Medical Service of your Department has arranged to have the tonsils and adenoids of my pupils removed. Dr. Sadlier in Sarnia has set the dates on June 22nd and 25th as the operating days. The children will stay in the hospital for three days.

I am willing to go if you think that it would be alright to close the school for the last week. Practically all the pupils will be going on one of the two days. Sir,

Last year you gave me permission to enter the pupils of this School in the County Musical Festival. I am anxious to do so again this year. It will be held in the afternoon, May 5th, in Sarnia. This necessitates a half-day away from the school and the part of the pupils and myself.

I feel that the participation of the children in this Festival is a direct benefit to them. This year they have provided the funds for their instruction themselves. The test piece is difficult and they have already spent many weeks on it. Naturally, they are keen to defend the trophy which they won last year. I shall be grateful for the necessary permission.

My experience last year was that after singing both afternoon and evening and then driving home a considerable distance there was a very poor attendance the following day, and those who did attend were very tired. The thought occurred to me that I might be allowed to teach one extra day before Easter and then close the school the day following the Festival. Would this arrangement be satisfactory, and in that event should I transfer the attendance from this to the next Quarter? We already have one extra day in, but that was included in last Quarter's Return. Through a mistake school was held on the present King's birthday.

Yours truly,

On Monday a.m., October 11, 1937, I received a call from Alfred GREENBURG, (Indian) from Kettle Pt., Indian Reservation complaining that the above mentioned held a party on Sunday Night, October 10, 1937, in the Indian School house at Kettle Point. This Indian complained that George Dill had liquor in the school room and when he went to see what was going on, he noticed men and women inside drinking stout beer. He entered and was offered a drink of Gin. He claims that he does not drink but took the bottle and tried to get out of the School room with it as evidence of what was going on and was beaten up by two of the men in the party, namely Jack Shepherd and Herb. Wettlaufer.

That a.m., accompanied by Cst.H.A.Dawson, I patrolled per Pol.Chev.,Coach,Code #2385, to the Kettle Point Indian Reserve to investigate the complaint. First going to the Greenburg home, I found there were four of them claiming to have seen Herb.Wettlaufer attempt to hit Alfred Greenburg with a baseball bat - which they turned over to me. Alfred told me the bottle of Gin got smashed when they were trying to get it away from him.

Going to the School-house, we found the benches moved back, the doors open and Mrs.Grant Milligan (an Indian woman whom Greenburg claims he saw sitting in at the party with a glass of liquor in her hand) in charge of the place and cleaning up after the party. She informed me that she was Mr.Dill's house-keeper and denied any knowledge of the goings-on the night previous. Examination of the School-room showed signs of the party by stains and blood on the floor, bearing out the Indians claim of a fight. At the door leading outside were hanging strips of wood upon which was found a considerable amount of black hair. Alfred Greenburg claimed they held him by the hair and beat him at the door.

A search of the place was made and while no liquor was found, there were a considerable number of empty beer bottles in the teacher's residence, which is built onto the School-house and is connected with the class-room by a door. At this point George Dill returned and readily admitted having a party there with liquor purchased on his Permit and having the liquor in the School-room, he did not remember seeing much of the fight. At the party was, Mrs.Nellie Mae FRANKS (white), Stratford,Ont., and at present living in her Summer Cottage at Ipperwash Beach. She was convicted here last Summer under Sec.42(1) of the Liquor Control Act and fined $100.00 and costs. With her was Herb.WETTLAUFER, who works for her and is said to be a bootlegger. There was also a Mrs.Maude HARRISON, from Chicago, Ill.,U.S.A.,now living with Mrs.Frank, Mr.and Mrs.Jack SHEPHERD, a well known bootlegger from Forest,Ont., was also there with his Brother Carl "Pitty" Shephord and Duncan BUTLER from Strathroy,Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that on Sunday evening, Oct. 10th, Mr. George Dill, teacher at the Kettle Point Indian Day School, held a Thanksgiving dinner and party at the teacher's residence at the Kettle Point School. At this party were 15 or 20 guests, white people. The tables were set in the class-room of the school and from reports received there was evidently liquor at the party and considerable noise. The liquor is alleged to have been kept in the school room.

Corporal Chisholm, R.C.M.P., reported the matter to me on Monday evening, Oct. 11th, and Mr. Dill also came to see me the same evening, along with some of the guests at the party. I took them around to see Corp. Chisholm, so that he might interview them. I would say that from reports on some of these people they should not have been allowed on the Reserve, especially at a party at the teacher's residence.

On Tuesday morning, Oct. 12th, Alfred Greenbird, and his father Beattie Greenbird, of the Kettle Point Band, called at the office and reported the party, stating that when Alfred Greenbird went to the School on Sunday evening to investigate the noise, he had entered the school room and attempted to seize a bottle of liquor there, after having been offered a drink. A fight ensued for possession of the liquor and Greenbird left without it. He later returned with his father, Beattie Greenbird, to the school to get the numbers of the cars, and claims he was attacked by one of the men with a baseball bat, belonging to the school. The Indians took the bat and later handed it over to Corp. Chisholm. Greenbird informed me he was laying a charge against two of the men at the party of assaulting him.

As Corp. Chisholm informed me he was making a report on the case, I decided to wait until the trial of the assault case, before making my report. The trial was held at Forest, on Oct. 15, and while the Magistrate dismissed the assault charge, he ordered

--that all--
that all the guests at the party be summoned, to appear before his court on a charge of consuming liquor in an illegal place, and that the case would be tried, either under the Indian Act, if the school house was part of the Reserve, or under the Liquor Control Act. I am enclosing, herewith, a copy of the Sarnia Canadian Observer with an account of the trial of the assault charge and the party.

I regret very much that this incident has happened. Mr. Dill called on me and admitted that the party had been held and that there was liquor in the class-room. He was evidently returning hospitality, which he had received during the summer, from the cottagers at Ipperwash Beach, but should certainly not have held his party at his residence or the class-room, nor on Sunday night, and one or two of the guests were people with whom he should not have any connection with, especially with regard to his position as teacher of the Kettle Point School.

As you will see, the matter has been given a lot of adverse publicity, not only for Mr. Dill, but for the Kettle Point School and Reserve as well. Mr. Dill is an exceptional teacher and has given fine service at this school. He has not only had the confidence and respect of the pupils, but of the parents as well. The Greenbird family were probably one of the few families who had anything against him. The school house was used as a community centre at nights by the residents of the Reserve, and the teacher was held in very high esteem. There is no doubt, however, this will lessen his influence over the children and his prestige on the Reserve.

While this is a matter for the decision of the Department, taking into consideration the excellent record of Mr. Dill as a teacher at Kettle Point School, I would strongly recommend that he be granted all the consideration possible. He is a single man, young, living alone on the Reserve, and no doubt thought he could have this party without it becoming known around the Reserve. As far as the report goes, of his having parties there all summer, I have never had any reports or complaints, nor have the Mounted Police. No doubt he had friends call on him over the week ends.

Any further information you may desire, I will be glad to forward.

Your obedient servant,

Re: John SHEPHERD (White) Forest, Ontario.
Assault. Sec., 291 C.C., of C.

1. Alfred Greenbird (Kettle Pt., Indian) laid a charge against the above mentioned and one H. Wetlaufer of Stratford, Ont., for assaulting him while he was trying to get a bottle of liquor out of the Kettle Pt., Indian School. (See my report dated October 13, 1937, re: George Dill. The name - Greenburg in this report should read "Greenbird" all through). Separate report submitted re:H. Wetlaufer.

The Crown and Defence Counsel agreed to have the evidence submitted in the WETLAUFER case apply in this case. So this defendant did not take the witness stand. The evidence brought out by the Crown Witnesses and Defence Witness H. Wetlaufer, showed that George Dill, Teacher for the Indian Dept., in the Kettle Pt., School for Indian children gave a party on Friday evening, October 10, 1937. This party was given in the School-room. The desks were moved back with liquor being served at the dinner and after and right in the class-room. As the students went into the Indian School to investigate, he said Mr. Dill offered him a drink of liquor and as he took the same he gave to the R.C.M.P., as evidence of the kind of party he had. Two men, Shepherd and Wetlaufer attacked him and he had the bottle. The only Defence witness called was Wetlaufer who admitted having a mix up with Alfred Greenbird and trying to get a bottle of liquor from him inside the Indian School, but denied having tried to hit him with the baseball bat outside the school.

The Magistrate said that the question he had was whether Greenbird had any legal justification for taking the liquor. If he had, then Wetlaufer and Shepherd could not be held responsible for assault. The Crown could not show where he had been assaulted so the case was dismissed. During the discussion His Worship asked Wetlaufer, "Were there 15 or 20 people there?" "No," replied the witness. "Was there a dinner in a class room of a school building?" "Yes," replied the witness. "Was there an Department for the education of Indians?" "Yes," replied the witness. "Was there any liquor being served?" "Yes, Sir," replied the witness. "It is a most disgraceful state of affairs that this can happen." "These 15 or 20 people," His Worship said, "were there to see every one be in front of this Court. Why there was no excuse that it was in the teacher's living quarters. Even if it is not on the Reserve, they can be here in the school. I do not care whether it comes under the Indian Act or not. It is either the Indian Act or the Liquor Act (Ontario)." "I never heard of such a thing. Who is this teacher anyway? If Dill is carrying liquor, there should be an investigation and Indians sufficiently interested. They don't seem to understand how I feel about this movement, and I want to insist that it is in the order of things."

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have been giving considerable thought to that unfortunate affair at Kettle Point. I am inclined to think that Mr. Dill has been the victim of a newspaper trial. At any rate, after making numerous inquiries from friends of mine who reside in the neighborhood of Kettle Point I believe that the story which he tells is substantially correct. He had a perfectly respectable dinner party—nine white people. One of his guests, Mr. Duncan Butler, engaged Wetlaufer to drive him from Ipperwash to the school. When Wetlaufer called for Mr. Butler about 10 o'clock he came into the school and brought Shepherd with him.

I doubt very much if he has ever had a drinking party in the school or in his apartments. People who are intimate with the people on the Reserve assure me that they had never heard a whisper of anything of that kind. And they feel that if rumors of that kind were in circulation they would have heard them.

The young man has succeeded in getting the Indians, both men and women, interested in the school. That the interest is real is evident from the fact that they have been paying out their own money to provide music in the school. They paid to provide transportation for the children to the musical festival and they are paying for a piano. I regard this as a very remarkable achievement.

I have no desire to advise you how you should deal with the matter. I do not know what you ought to do. If he still holds the confidence and esteem of his pupils and of the people on the Reserve I presume you will have less difficulty in reaching a decision.

I remain,

Yours truly,

WOMAN FINED $10 FOR SCHOOL PARTY

Liquor Present at Indian Celebration

Sarnia, Oct. 30—Mrs. Nellie Mae Franks of Stratford was fined $10 in an Indian reserve court for selling liquor to a party in the Kettle Point Indian school. Among those present were the teacher at the school and her husband.

The charges were laid as a sequel to the case in Fenelon Falls where Herbert Wettlaufer was accused of assault with intent.

The alleged offence occurred when Greenberg entered the school grounds and attempted to seize a bottle of liquor. The assault charge was dropped.

Montreal, Oct. 30—Announcement of the death of Mrs. Louise Vialu was made.

The woman's body was found on a dark street last night. Detectives quickly traced her to a nearby spot where she was struck by an automobile when they noted her shoes were dry. Apparently rain having fallen all evening. The woman's body was found near the spot, with contents apparently intact.

The 45-year-old mother of five children, Mrs. Vialu was known to police as a witness in a case when her husband was under detention as a crown witness in another case.

Vialu was being held as a material witness for the defense.

Detectives believe the woman was thrown from an automobile. When they arrived at the scene suggesting murder, they called police.

OUT OF PROPORTION

New York, Oct. 30—Prediction that many newspapers may be forced to raise their circulation rates because of rising newspaper costs came today from W. G. Chandler, chairman of the board of directors of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

Chandler already has asked publishers to protest to newspaper manufacturers for prospective price increases for the newspapers in more than 50 cities of the United States, taken to raise their rates recently because of increased costs, he said.

Costs of newspaper publishing according to statistics tabulated here, have been recorded for out of proportion to increased receipts from advertising and circulation. Costs have jumped ahead of even the most feverish increase in expenses and from additional employment, while receipts have remained below the normal advance.

PAYS FINE OVER SCHOOL PARTY

Stratford Woman Settles in Lambton Court

EIGHT PAID PREVIOUSLY

Charges Laid Over Thanksgiving Party

SARNIA, Oct. 29 — Mrs. Nellie Mae Franks, of Stratford, charged with having liquor on an Indian reserve paid a fine of $10 and posted into magistrate's court here today. The charge followed a Thanksgiving party in the Kettle Point Indian schoolhouse. Eight other persons paid similar fines yesterday, among them George Dill, teacher at the school and Mr. and Mrs. Robert Casey, of two others, Herbert Wettlaufer and Mrs. Maude Harrison, both of Stratford, have still to be disposed of.

The charges were laid as a sequel to a court case last week in Forest where Wettlaufer was accused with assaulting Albert Greenberg, Kettle Point Indian. The alleged offence occurred when Greenberg entered the schoolhouse when the party was in progress and attempted to seize a bottle of liquor which he claimed turned over to police. The assault charge was dismissed. Magistrate C. S. Woodrow holding the complainant was not justified in his actions of seizing the liquor.

Memorandum:

THE DEPUTY MINISTER,

In a letter dated November 5, 1937, from the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, I am advised that Mr. George Dill, teacher of the Kettle Point Indian Day School (Electoral District of Lambton-Kent), Sarnia Indian Agency, was convicted on November 2nd for possessing intoxicants on an Indian reserve, under Section 130 of the Indian Act.

This was the culmination of a party given by the teacher in the Kettle Point School on Thanksgiving Day. All the guests at this party were also convicted under Section 130 of the Indian Act.

Newspaper clippings that have been forwarded to us indicate that this case received very wide publicity in southwestern Ontario. The Police Magistrate criticized Mr. Dill very severely.

Mr. Dill has been in our employ for the past 8 years as he was first employed at the Sucker Creek Indian Day School and for the past 4 years at the Kettle Point School. As a teacher, his services have been quite satisfactory.

However, in view of the publicity given this case and the further fact that he was convicted under a Section of the Indian Act, I feel that the Department has no alternative than to dispense with his services. If his employment is continued, it is probable that such action would have a bad effect, not only on the Indians but on other Indian school teachers. In addition, the Department is quite likely to be subject to criticism from outside sources.

With the above in mind, I therefore recommend that Mr. Dill be advised that his services will not be required after December 31, 1937, and I would appreciate receiving your concurrence in order that Mr. Dill may be so notified before the end of the current month.

Director.

I have seen Mr. Down and have asked for time to communicate with you before giving him a reply.

I have simply one request to make - that whatever action you take be withheld until the end of the academic year in June.

My principle reasons are:
1. I have been carrying on experimental work, as you know, in social studies and the sciences. I have arrived at the stage where my results are giving the information which I need to standardize and evaluate the work. Naturally, an interruption at this point would mean a serious set-back to that work.

2. The work and accomplishments of the Teachers' Association has been on the greatest interest to me. To this date I have carried on the Executive work practically alone because of the difficulty of distance between members. As I explained to you in my report of last month I accepted the Presidency for only one more year with the understanding that I should gradually pass the management on to the members of the Executive - especially to Mr. Daly who succeeds me as President.

3. My leaving at this time would make it virtually impossible to go into another school and thus the only training that I have would be useless to me.

I have given my work in the Department always as a work of devotion and have attacked it with every power and energy at my command. Through the winters I have given my own leisure to the community life of the Reserve in keeping the school open. I have never hesitated to supply the financial backing to this work or to the extra-curricular activities of the students.
I think that I can carry on without any ill-effects to the school as the attendance has kept up and there is no evidence of unrest.

If you are able to consider a postponement of your decision in the light of the above I shall be grateful.

PERSONAL REPORT FOR THE MONTH OF MARCH, 1941.

I have visited all schools in the Agency and will continue my reports on the progress as I find it. You will remember in my report for the month of February I said I was disappointed. I am still a little disappointed with Kettle & Stony Point Schools. I do not attribute this entirely to the teachers although I think sometimes they get a little discouraged. The percentage of children with any inclination to learn is small. The others show an utter disregard. I had a long talk with Mr. Howard, the teacher of Kettle Point School, and he tells me he has been taking a mental I.Q. of the Indians at Kettle Point School and he finds they have an average of sixty. Whether or not this is an excuse, I am not prepared to say. I am of the opinion that more effort should be made to memorize their work. It is appalling! You go over a lesson thoroughly—you ask the class a question—give them the answer—review the lesson in the next five minutes and they can't answer.

Kettle Point was the dummy school for the month of February. Stony Point showed some signs of improvement although I think they had concentrated on Lambton Country the whole month. But even so that if progress can be made we are at least accomplishing a little. The children at St. Clair are so much more advanced and have a good knowledge of their lessons. With the exception of two or three, any question is readily answered although I am told the Provincial Inspector's report on St. Clair School is not very good. I am inclined to think there is a little vindictiveness in his reports. He and Mr. Smith have clashed on occasions. I thought of asking Mr. Howard and Mr. Tompkins to outline their lessons in the form of stories. It may help them to memorize, and instead of attempting a general knowledge, to concentrate on one subject until they have learned it thoroughly. What think you? Or would it interfere with the school curriculum as laid down by the Province? Reading and arithmetic can be classed about the same—St. Clair quite good, Kettle & Stony Point fair to bad. The writing in all schools is exceptional. There are some beautiful writers. This only tends to strengthen my opinion on manual and vocational training. We see something through the eye and catch on quickly. Writing, painting, drawing, whittling with a jack knife or using tools of any kind are some of the things they love to do; but give them a mathematical or geographical lesson and they are not interested. Compared with February, I would say there is a little improvement.

Geo. W. Down,
Indian Agent,

PERSONAL REPORT FOR THE MONTH OF MAY, 1941.

Dear Sir:

SCHOOLS:

All schools have been visited and I am happy to report a decided improvement in all grades. It was my pleasure to meet Inspector Edwards of the Provincial Educational Department at Kettle Point School. After a short lesson with the children and a discussion with the teacher, it was decided a definite improvement had been made and the Inspector was very much impressed with the eagerness of the children to answer questions, although he seemed to emphasize the need for more academic training. I still question the advisability of this as far as our Indian population is concerned, and still question the assimilation of the subject matter rather than the memorizing of the subject. In fact, I think the greatest benefit to the greatest number of our Indian children could be achieved by a greater concentration on Manual and Vocational training. However, to carry on this type of work successfully one needs rather more than the allotted amount, also at least a part-time teacher qualified in the arts of Manual Training. But, I realize at this time the restricted funds available for this purpose.

PERSONAL REPORT FOR THE MONTH OF JUNE, 1941.

Dear Sir:

SCHOOLS:

All schools have been visited and with the closing for the summer holidays, I think, perhaps, a short report on the term progress and management would be appropriate. The pupils and teachers together with myself have found our monthly lessons and tests of some benefit. Whether or not the benefits will be carried through the vacation period is another question. Three months is a long time for any child to be out of school and almost a calamity for an Indian. However, we can only hope to pick up from where we left off.

Kettle Point with Mr. Vivian Howard has shown at least one outstanding accomplishment, that is an appreciable increase of pupils. He now has 42 on the roll. This, in itself, until the young pupils adjust themselves, has a tendency to distract the attention of the other classes. The attendance at this school has fallen back during the last month. Mr. Howard thinks this may, in part, be attributed to the fact that we have dispensed with the Truant Officer. Just what is wrong at this school I do not know. The children are not disciplined and a lack of co-operation is very noticeable. This is not the fault of Mr. Howard. I think he has made every effort to co-operate with the children and parents but he has had occasion to check several of the children and in some cases send them home to be cleaned up. This, of course, has been resented. However, in the academic studies I think the children have made worthwhile progress. In manual and vocational training I do not think Mr. Howard is very interested. He claims to be a modern artist. Should that mean anything to our Indian school? I am not sure. Certainly the school is well placarded with art.

PERSONAL REPORT FOR THE MONTH OF DECEMBER, 1941.

Dear Sir:

SCHOOLS, HEALTH AND RELIEF

All schools were visited during the month and I found nothing of a serious nature to report. The attendance at Kettle & Stony Point was under the average. This can, perhaps, be attributed to an outbreak of Whooping Cough. Otherwise, the health of our children and people generally is very good.

Geo. W. Down,
Indian Agent.
SARNIA, Ontario,
January 7, 1942.

Personal Report for the Month of December, 1941.

Dear Sir:

CHECKING back over the months of 1941 and from my personal observations I would say the progress made is fair, at least, compared with other years and the type of pupil to work on. The children attending the St. Clair school on the Sarnia Reserve seem to be a superior type to the Kettle & Stony Point children. Why this should be I do not know. In discussing conditions and the problems of the Teachers one is led to believe that the teaching of Indian children is reserved for martyrs of the profession.

However, throughout the year a steady program of the academic curriculum has been followed and wherever possible, under the limited facilities, manual and vocational training has been given.

Kettle & Stony Point continues to lag behind with a noticeable lack of co-operation between parents and teachers. The end of 1941 is no better than the end of 1940. The attendance and interest at Stony Point does not justify a school. This question was taken up during the summer holidays and a promise of regular attendance was assured. I am afraid it was an empty promise.

Very little has been spent in the repair, and upkeep of any of the schools in the agency, but I am hoping some repairs can be arranged during 1942.

Geo. W. Down,
Indian Agent.

Attention: Mr. R. A. Hoey.

Re: Attendance, Kettle Pt. School.

On the date of my last visit to Kettle Point Indian Day School, Mr. Howard, the teacher, referred to Departmental letter 29-2-1 of January 26, 1943 which was addressed to him and a copy forwarded to this office. Mr. Howard gave quite a lengthy outline of the conditions giving rise to irregular attendance at this school. After thoroughly discussing the matter with him, I am convinced that he is earnestly endeavouring to remedy the low attendance. For some unexplained reason, there seems to be little or no cooperation from the Indian parents. In my opinion, it is not possible for Mr. Howard to overcome this merely through his own efforts. The children who do attend more or less regularly are making good progress.

Mr. Howard prepared a detailed report regarding attendance during the December quarter and I am submitting it for Departmental consideration.

The principal reasons for the poor showing in the attendance for the term ending December 1942 of Kettle Point School, were:

1. Several of the children worked on farms and at the celery gardens during October and part of November.
2. Six children from three families moved away in November--
no attendance in December. They will probably all come back in the spring.

3. Some of the families from Stony Point were late in moving and their children did not enter till November.

4. One boy came for one day and because the distance from the Point was too far did not come again. They may move closer.

5. The Milliken girls—one spastic and the other mentally retarded—come only when the mother could bring them in the car. One came two days and the other ten days.

6. Many of the families start the children in the fall and then keep the younger ones out during the worst weather. There were an unusual number of stormy days during December.

Causes for absence in Spring Term.

1. Cutting wood—So many of the fathers are working, the mothers have to cut wood and take boys or girls out to help.

2. In the spring fishing—carp—one of my boys and his seventeen-year-old brother caught 1500 lbs. in one day. Prices have been rising steadily—5¢ per lb. last Spring.

3. Frogging—This affects Edgar Shawanoo's family. He takes the children out to catch frogs to sell to restaurants. They make good money.

4. Children of school age working on farms.

5. Bad weather and cold mornings.
