REPORT ON SARNIA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF MAY, 1943.

St. Clair and Kettle Point Indian Day Schools were open throughout the month. The attendance at the St. Clair School was much lower than usual due to the measles epidemic. At Kettle Point the attendance remained about the same. Mr. Howard, teacher of Kettle Point School, was immediately informed of the Departmental decision to dispense with his services at the end of June. Pending Departmental instructions, no action has been taken to secure another teacher. In view of the great scarcity of teachers, I believe we are going to experience considerable difficulty in procuring a fully qualified one. In my opinion, this matter should be given immediate Departmental attention as later on all teachers will have obtained schools. The teacher of the St. Clair School on the Sarnia Reserve has not definitely made up her mind as to whether she will continue or not. She appears to be a very satisfactory teacher.

M.W. McCracken,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON SARNIA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JUNE, 1943.

The St. Clair and Kettle Point Schools were open throughout June. The teacher of the St. Clair School, Mrs. Thompson, is willing to continue as teacher of the School for the 1943-44 year. No teacher has, as yet, been secured to replace Mr. Howard at Kettle Point. In accordance with Department instructions, I wrote to Mr. Edwards, I.P.S., requesting assistance in obtaining a teacher for Kettle Point School but, to date, I have not received a reply. It appears as though teachers are very scarce and we shall be fortunate if we secure a qualified one at Kettle Point. The attendance at Kettle Point was unsatisfactory as many pupils remained home without cause. Others accepted employment without permission of the teacher or this office. The measles epidemic on Sarnia Reserve tended to lower the attendance at the St. Clair School. Both of the schools will need some repairs this summer. I shall report concerning this work under separate cover.

M.W. McCracken,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON SARNIA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JULY, 1943.

I was pleased to learn that the Department has been successful in securing the services of a teacher for the Kettle Point School. After inspecting the School, I find that it requires only a few minor repairs such as replacement of a few broken window panes, etc. The former teacher, Mr. Howard, has vacated the teacher's residence. The school residence and garage were securely locked when he left but in spite of this some unknown person or persons gained entrance to the basement. No damage resulted and only a few jars of fruit were stolen. There is no Indian Constable at Kettle Point and I therefore asked a reliable Indian who lives near the school to guard the premises. There is a gang of exceedingly destructive and irresponsible Indian youths around Kettle Point who appear to take great delight in damaging and destroying property. It is practically impossible to apprehend them as they are very sly and Indians of the Reserve do not voluntarily offer any clues as to their identity.

M.W. McCracken,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON SARNIA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH NOVEMBER, 1943.

Day Schools were open throughout the month. The attendance at Kettle Point has been excellent and the new teacher, Miss Fairservice, is doing remarkably well. In all matters connected with the school there has been a decided improvement and Miss Fairservice deserves a great deal of credit. The school is clean, tidy, and the pupils seem to have an entirely different attitude in comparison with last year. The teacher of the St. Clair School, Mrs. Thompson, submitted her resignation which is to be effective as from December 31, 1943. She has secured a school in the white municipality near her home where the salary is much higher and the attendance smaller. I have already written the Department regarding this matter. In my opinion, it will be very difficult to secure another teacher for the St. Clair School as teachers are very scarce at the present time.

M.W. McCracken,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON SARNIA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF DECEMBER, 1943.

The St. Clair and Kettle Point Day Schools were open in December. Excellent results are being achieved by the teacher at Kettle Point. Christmas entertainments were held in the schools under the supervision of the teachers, and the Indian parents at Kettle Point were quite pleased with the performance of their children. The teacher of the St. Clair School resigned with effect December 31, 1943. On instructions from the Department I advertised for a teacher but no applications were received. To date the St. Clair School is without a teacher. Many Indians of the Sarnia Reserve blame the Chief of the Band as Mrs. Thompson would not have resigned if he had not criticized her to the extent of publishing his views in the local paper. The teacher did not resign wholly on account of this criticism but it did play a part.

M.W. McCracken,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON SARNIA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JANUARY, 1944.

The Kettle Point Indian Day School was open throughout January with a satisfactory attendance reported by the teacher. Parents at Kettle Point appear more interested in the progress of their children than they did last year. The improvement in the attitude and progress of the children is due almost entirely to the new teacher who is doing excellent work. The St. Clair Indian Day School on the Sarnia Reserve remained closed all month as no teacher was procured. About one fourth of the pupils who formerly attended the Reserve school are now enrolled in various city schools. The city schools are accepting new pupils on a temporary basis providing they pay $6.00 per month per pupil. If we secure a teacher, these pupils will likely return to the St. Clair School to save fees and transportation difficulties.

Recently, an application was received at this office from Miss Elford, a qualified teacher who has had considerable experience with Indian pupils at other Reserves. I have forwarded her written application to the Department for consideration. If appointed, Miss Elford would not be able to commence duties until about April 1st, 1944.

M.W. McCracken,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

At the regular monthly Council Meeting of the Kettle Point Band held on March 9, 1944, the following Resolution was passed:

"Moved by Chief Milliken, seconded by Thomas Bressette that this Council request the Department to provide an additional classroom at the Kettle Point School as the present classroom is not large enough to accommodate all pupils." Carried.

At the present time, there is an enrolment of forty-eight at this school. Some members of the Band who have children of school age are working in white communities. If all of these families returned to the Reserve, the accommodation at Kettle Point School would certainly be inadequate. There is also one member of the Band living at Thedford who has children of school age. It is expected that he will be taking up residence at Kettle Point in the near future and if so the enrolment will exceed fifty.

During the past year, the teacher has been forced to seat two pupils in many desks. This is an undesirable situation and works to the disadvantage of the pupils as well as the teacher. Miss Feirservice is of the opinion that the classroom at Kettle Point is overcrowded. After Easter, I understand that several kindergarten pupils will be beginning which will further tax the seating accommodation. It is quite apparent that an additional classroom is needed at this school. Kindly advise if arrangements might be made whereby an addition could be built to the school in the near future.

M. W. McCracken,
INDIAN AGENT.

The St. Clair Indian Day School remained closed during February. A teacher has been obtained but will not be available for duty until about April 1st, 1944. Indians of the Sarnia Band are pleased that a qualified teacher has been secured. The Kettle Point School was open throughout the month. Dear Mr. Meadows:

Dr. Corrigan, in a telegram received at this Branch, intimates that you might be interested in the position of teacher at the Kettle Point 2-room Indian Day School, Sarnia Agency, Ontario.

The Kettle Point School is situated on the southern end of Lake Huron, 25 miles from Sarnia and 3 miles from Forest. Forest, I may state, is on the Canadian National line, running between Toronto and Sarnia. This school has been until now the ordinary Indian day school with teacher's residence attached. However, we have made arrangements for the construction of an additional room and it is our hope that this work will be undertaken and completed prior to September 1.

In view of the acute shortage of teachers, we are naturally anxious to secure two teachers for this school, preferably a man and his wife. We would be prepared to pay $1,000 for the principal and $800 for the assistant, plus furnished residence, plus cost-of-living bonus in both cases.

These Indians, with limited land resources in a well settled district, usually find employment in industries in Canada and in the United States. The courses of study provided are somewhat similar to the courses of study provided in the ordinary public school in Ontario. We would like, however, to secure a teacher who would be able to provide worthwhile vocational courses.

This is a departmentally-operated school, that is to say, the teachers have not been, in the past, nominated by the church authorities. While we would be naturally anxious to secure your services for this school,

Welfare and Training:

The St. Clair Indian Day School was open throughout the quarter. A number of Indians and particularly Chief Adams blame the Department for not having provided adequate educational facilities for children of the Sarnia Reserve. Chief Adams is very bitter and openly and harshly accused the Department of inefficiency and neglect. Miss Florence Elford, junior teacher of the St. Clair School, is a staunch supporter of the Chief and encourages him to agitate and criticize. Miss Fairervice is doing excellent work as senior teacher at Kettle Point.

Education

In August and September plans to erect a new two-room school on Sarnia Reserve were formulated. The Shaw Construction Company of Sarnia has been engaged to erect this building and actual construction on the present school site will commence in the very near future.

The schools on Sarnia and Kettle Point Reserves were opened on September 4th with a large increase of pupils, particularly juniors. I wish to refer to my letter of September 17th and Departmental reply 29-2-1 (W.T.l) of September 24th regarding pupils in the junior room of Kettle Point School.

The arrangement whereby Grade 1 pupils attend in the morning and Grades 2 and 3 in the afternoon does not appear to be satisfactory to the majority of Indian parents. Many of them are not sending their Grade 3 children as they do not consider it is worth while for half a day. Parents of children in Grades 1 and 2 are objecting to the fact that their children do not get a full day.

After careful consideration Mrs. Clemens and I have decided to revert back to the original arrangement whereby children in Grades 1 and 2 attend all day and pupils in Grades 3 to 8 will have to remain at home until a senior teacher is available.

Ottawa, March 25th, 1947.

Dear Miss Gibson:

With reference to your letter of the 13th instant, if you accept the work at Kettle Point Day School you will be required to teach grades four to eight for the months of May and June, and possibly another grade for the months of July and August.

It is a two room school and we have had only one teacher since September last but the Indians have agreed to send their children during the summer months due to the fact that the senior grades have lost time during the past few months.

It is not actually an Indian village; the Indians are scattered for several miles along Lake Huron. Furnished living quarters for both teachers are attached to the school.

There are usually a large number of white people living in summer resorts either on the reserve or close to the reserve. The Kettle Point Indians are a very quiet group and we have never had any trouble with them. We have an Indian Agent residing at Sarnia, Ontario, which is approximately thirty-five miles away. He makes regular visits to the reserve. The nearest town is Forest, Ontario, approximately five miles away.

We are prepared to allow salary of $131. a teaching month.

The residence at Kettle Point is very small but the Junior teacher, Mrs. Clemens, definitely does not require the use of it and this would leave the accommodation solely for the Senior teacher. There are two bedrooms and I think Mrs. Fielding and her family could reside in the quarters without crowding. According to her letter Mr. Fielding is not likely to occupy the residence for any considerable period.

There is another point which causes concern and that is accommodating these white children in the Junior and Senior classrooms. No doubt you are aware that both of these classrooms are already taxed to capacity and it appears as though the situation may be aggravated without the addition of five white children.

However, Mrs. Fielding's application is the only one which I have received for Kettle Point and this school may be without a teacher at all if her application is rejected on account of the size of her family. She is well-qualified and after careful consideration of all angles of the case I recommend that she be appointed as it would be very unfortunate if the Senior room remained closed a second year for lack of a teacher. I think we could, somehow, accommodate Mrs. Fielding and her family in the residence and also in the classrooms.

M. W. McCracken,
Indian Agent.

We have your letter of the 23rd ultimo enclosing the application of Mrs. H.B. Fielding for the position of teacher at the Kettle Point School.

We have had similar experiences at other schools in the past and invariably trouble arises.

Dear Miss Reeser:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of September 10th re accepting appointment as teacher of the senior classroom of Kettle Point Indian Day School.

Colonel Neary's statement re enrolment of approximately forty is correct and I think arrangements could be made whereby you would teach grades four to eight inclusive. In my previous letter I mentioned grades three to eight due to the fact that the junior room is crowded but I think the junior teacher could handle grades one, two and three inclusive.

I cannot promise that the hydro will be in by Christmas as materials are very scarce. The Hydro Commission in Forest is prepared to erect a line when materials become available. The Department in Ottawa has already authorized the instalment of hydro and are very anxious to procure electric service for the convenience of the teacher. Until such time as hydro is available I feel certain that some satisfactory arrangement re renting or borrowing a battery radio could be made. The existing telephone line is about one-half mile from the school and I would have to investigate the possibility of extending the line to serve the teacher's residence. It is doubtful if the telephone company would erect a line to serve one customer, but I have no detailed information on this at the moment.

The residence is completely furnished and any sheets, towels, table linen, etc., which is required could be purchased immediately. The university student who taught this classroom from May until the end of August occupied the residence and left it in a clean and orderly condition.

Mr. Arneil is our Inspector and he visits this Agency quite frequently. I am sure he would be pleased to assist in delivery of your books but I do not know when he intends to make his next visit this way.

In the event that you accept the position you might contact me at my office on the second floor of the Post Office Building in Sarnia. The office telephone number is 540. I would meet you at the station if you care to call upon arrival.

Yours very truly,

Sarnia, September 9th, 1947.

Miss Irene Reeser,
LOCUST HILL, Ontario.

Dear Miss Reeser:

I have your letter making enquiries as to the residence and school at Kettle Point Indian Reserve and in reply would advise as follows:- The school is of frame construction with residence attached. It is a two-room school but the junior teacher, who is on duty now, does not require use of the residence as she lives on a farm about two miles from Kettle Point. The school is located on a good gravel road about one-half mile from a paved provincial highway. It is six miles from the town of Forest and about two miles from a country store called Ravenswood.

The enrolment in the senior room for the current academic year would be about thirty-five or possibly a few more. You would be required to teach grades three to eight inclusive.

The residence contains a fair-sized basement, kitchen, living-room and two bedrooms upstairs. It is completely furnished. There is also a separate frame woodshed with garage attached. There is no hydro in the school but we intend to have same installed as soon as materials become available. It does not have running water but there is a good well on the school grounds. The necessary coal and wood required to heat the school and residence is paid for by the Indian Affairs Branch. When and if hydro is installed it would be a 25 cycle service.

To get to Kettle Point from Toronto you could come to Sarnia by C.N.R. Railway or by bus. I would then be glad to transport you in my car from Sarnia to Kettle Point which is about thirty-five miles. There is train and bus service between Sarnia and Forest.

At the present time the senior room is closed as we have not been able to obtain a teacher. I trust that the above answers most of your questions regarding the school and residence but if further information is desired I shall be glad to furnish same.

Yours very truly,

M. W. McCracken,

INSPECTION REPORT

Junior Room - Kettle Point Indian Day School - October 8, 1947.

Teacher - Mrs. Clemens

Grade I - 13
Grade II - 16
Grade III - 5

This is an elderly teacher with a nice manner in handling little children. Classroom is bright and attractive with posters and flowers making it cheerful for the pupils. There are individual cups for the children and wash basins with towels. The discipline is none too strict. On the other hand the relationship between the teacher and the pupils is such that the children speak out clearly and plainly. Mrs. Clemens is a motherly type of woman and it is obvious that the pupils are interested in their work and want to please the teacher. There is probably more walking around and freedom in talking than one would like but the teacher has complete control of the situation.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Ottawa, February 13, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, informing the Department of the illness of Mr. H. D. Watts, teacher of the Kettle Point Indian Day School.

In this connection it is noted that there were few children attending school previous to the teacher's illness and that a number of the children are ill at the present time. It is hoped that Mr. Watts will be able to resume duties at an early date, and, in the meantime, this school may remain closed.

Mr. Watts, in preparing his return for the current quarter, should state therein the dates between which the school was closed on account of his illness.

Ottawa, July 18, 1933.

Sir:

It has been decided to appoint Mr. George Dill as teacher of the Kettle Point Indian Day School. Mr. Dill has had considerable experience in other Indian schools and is the holder of a second class professional certificate. Mr. Dill will be at Kettle Point in time to re-open the school on September 5th, next.

The salary allowed this teacher will be at the same rate as was paid the former teacher, viz.: $85 per teaching month, less 10%.

The Department trusts that you will give Mr. Dill every possible assistance in his work at this school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. C. McCormick, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Kettle Point Indian Day School, No. 401.

In my memorandum of May 17, 1944, I advised you that the former teacher, Miss Ida G. Fairservice, would give up duties at the above-mentioned school on July 1, 1944.

Ottawa, October 13th, 1894.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your Report on the Kettle Point Indian School for the month of September last in which you state that the building is in a very bad state of repair and too near the road.

In reply I beg to say that it would have been better had you called the attention of the Department to this state of affairs early in the season so that the necessary repairs could have been made during the holidays.

The Department would like you however to give a detailed estimate of the cost of such material and labour as is absolutely required to make the building habitable for the coming winter and nothing more.

In all cases when you recommend repairs to be done this information should be given.

Your obedient servant,

Acting Deputy Supt. General
of Indian Affairs.

Adam English, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sarnia,
Ont.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of 11th inst.

I beg to report that with reference to the school work at Kettle Point, after the receipt of your letter in midsummer I got the walls all fixed up temporarily. The main thing that was wrong was that the boards were loose some at one end and come altogether. Mrs. Bessette did the work and I added $25 to her bill for cleaning the school to pay for her extra trouble - when I saw the walls last they were all right and with due respect to her work I do not think now there is very much wrong yet but Mrs. Bessette used old screw nails and I noticed some of them were not holding very well - I will get new screw nails and perhaps the teacher will put them in. I had noticed the roof was leaking a little and asked Chief Milliken to get the roof repaired. The shingles are there now. I expect it is done now but if not it will be directly.

With reference to the floor, it is worn through in spots around the stove and could be repaired for ten dollars by patching. There is a concrete foundation so that no wind gets in below but the plan you suggest of course would make a better job. From the teacher's platform to the door would be about 60 or 65 superficial feet which would cost thirty or thirty-five dollars for a good soft maple dressed floor.

I spoke to some parties in Sarnia but of course Sarnia is so distant from there that mechanics do not come to undertake the work and could not do so without a considerable advance over that for which parties resident at Forest or Thedford could. REPORT OF INSPECTOR H. CONN ON THE KETTLE POINT DAY SCHOOL... SARNIA.

The class room is 24 feet long by 15 ft. wide and the average height is about 11 feet. The air space, consequently, amounts to approximately 4000 cu.ft. The Ontario Education requires the trustees to provide 250 cu.ft. of air space for each pupil (based on the maximum daily attendance). Judged by this standard, class room of this school has air space for 16 pupils and there is an enrolment of 31. It is therefore evident that the school is greatly overcrowded.

I note cement on the grounds for the purpose of putting a cover on the well. The old well should be filled.

Memorandum for Mr. Scott.

I beg to inform you that on October 27 last I made an inspection of the Kettle Point School and site with a view of recommending temporary repairs to the school in an effort to make them more comfortable during the winter weather.

The school building is of frame, old and in poor condition and will not warrant any expenditure in repairs to the building. The building is also inadequate in accommodation being 24' x 15' 6" with 11 foot ceiling which only provides space for 16 pupils while there are double that number enrolled (32), and an average attendance of 18.

A resolution of this band under date of September 6 last requests that a school be built at once, with a request from the Agent that living accommodation be provided for the teacher.

It is impossible to erect the building this year, arrangements should, however, be made for an early start in the Spring.

The plans prepared for Ryerson School provide the accommodation necessary for pupils available as well as for the teachers, and I would recommend that a print of this building be sent to the Agent for the band's approval if satisfactory and in the event of changes being necessary these can be made and specifications prepared at an early
date. A site on the school lot near the present building is satisfactory and will not interfere with the conducting of school in the present building while the new one is being erected.

Architect.

Memorandum:—

Hon. Mr. Meighen,

The Kettle Point school on the Sarnia Indian reserve, which is of frame construction, is so old and dilapidated that it is beyond repair. The present building has accommodation for 16 pupils, while there are 32 enrolled.

It is proposed to erect a new building, sufficiently commodious to accommodate the pupils.

In 1916 we endeavoured to erect a new building, but received no tenders in response to our advertisement. The band has passed a resolution to have the amount taken from its Capital Funds, which now amount to $147,953.92. It is estimated that this school building will cost in the neighbourhood of $5,500.00, and, as it is absolutely necessary, I would ask your authority to have the expenditure made.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir,

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, and in reply beg to say that it is noted that you have made arrangements to have the closets at the Kettle Point Indian Day School repaired and put in good condition.

With reference to the purchase of a new stove to replace the one in use at present which is unsafe, I beg to say that you should obtain competitive prices from a number of dealers handling stoves of the kind required and you may purchase a suitable stove from the firm quoting the lowest price. POOR COPY
I am taking this opportunity to bring to your attention the necessity for a new school building at Kettle Point.

The present school house is altogether too small for the number enrolled. The desks are crowded too closely together and it is necessary in some instances to seat three pupils at one double desk. The building itself is old and rather than spend any money on repairs it would be advisable to erect a new school with teacher's residence included.

The parents are taking more interest in sending their children to school and are anxious to have better accommodation.

In this connection it would be as well to give some consideration to a central school for the two reserves. From a casual survey of the situation, I think that this is a matter which Schools Branch should give careful consideration. There are never more than ten or eleven pupils at Stony Point School. This seems to be too few to warrant the expense of upkeep and teacher's salary. The Kettle Point school would be better situated if built up on the hill, near the church. This would bring it much closer to Stony Point reserve and an arrangement could probably be made for transportation of pupils daily to the school and return. I mention this only as a suggestion for consideration and not as a proposition, which has been given careful thought. I do, however, strongly recommend a new school for Kettle Point reserve and that the location be changed to a more central point.
November 25, 1924.

MEMO FOR FILE:

I have discussed with Mr. Inspector Parker and Mr. MacKenzie, both of whom have looked into school matters at Kettle Point and Stony Point, and I believe that the present building at Stony Point should be used as long as there are sufficient pupils available to warrant the activity. At Kettle Point a combined school and residence should be erected at the first opportunity, on a site near the church. The Band Capital Account shows $44,912.06. Mr. Parker informs me that they will be under heavy expense for roads, etc., during the next few years and he recommends that a Vote of Parliament be secured. I am trying to arrange to have the money provided for the building season of 1925.
**Indian Trust Fund**

Ottawa, April 15, 1925.

Sir:

I beg to advise you that Mr. R.G. Orr, Architect of the Department, will be in Sarnia sometime next week to make arrangements for the building of a new combined day school and teachers' residence at Kettle Point, and I would ask you to give him all the assistance you can in selecting out a suitable site and also arranging for the erection of the proposed building.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean
Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Thomas Paul, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sarnia, Ont.
Ottawa, April 29, 1925.

Dear Mr. Paul:

As you have been informed by the Department Architect, it is the intention to erect this year a combined school and residence at Kettle Point. The funds of the Indian band will not be used for this purpose, as I am arranging for an appropriation by Parliament, which will be sufficient to complete the building programme. It is the intention to engage Indian labour for the activity.

A suitable site is necessary and Mr. Orr has informed me that you are going to approach the Indian council at their next meeting, with a view to securing a proper lot. Please have them pass a resolution, setting aside at least one acre in the lots shown on the plan of the reserve as held by Wesley and Stephen Shawkense. Proper compensation will be allowed to the Indian owner of the site selected. I understand that you were acquainted with the best locations at the time of Mr. Orr's visit. You may assure the council that this lot will be used for school purposes only.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Thos. Paul, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sarnia, Ont.

Sept. 5th, 1931.

Sir:

Replying to your letter of Sept. 5th regarding the expenditure of $8.00 for work done at Kettle Pt. School. Probably I am in the wrong by having this work done without authority from the Department, but it was absolutely necessary before school opened.

The well had to be cleaned out, one of the out buildings was blown over and the roof smashed off, they also needed cleaning out. I got Chief Sam Bressette to do the work and he completed it.

Sam Bressette wanted $10.00 for the work, but I considered it rather high and allowed him $8.00. I do not consider the charges are unreasonable, and would recommend payment.

In future, I will be a little more careful regarding expenditure.

Your obedient servant,

J. C. McCormick
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Helen,

As has been pointed out by your agent, and by the School Inspector, both the interior and exterior of the school are badly in need of painting.

It would, of course, be impossible to have the exterior done at present, but, the thought occurred to me that the schoolroom itself could be done during the Easter recess. The room has insufficient light to meet the required standards, and it would help if the ceiling were painted, and the walls kalsomined. The walls are of beaver board, and would have to be sized first. Each of the ceilings and the walls would require two coats of paint or kalsomine. The ceiling is of tin, and I am inclined to think that the paint would be better.

The labor could be secured on the Reserve. If there is any possibility of having this done at this time, I should be only too glad to have an estimate of the work made, and to submit this estimate to Mr. Agent McCormick.

I shall be grateful for your kind consideration of this matter.

Forest, Ont.,
June 16th, 1934.

Dear Phil,

There are two or three little matters that I should like to clear up before the end of the year.

1. I enclose the accounts for the screening of the verandah. This seems to be the only thing to do as Mr. McCormick is still not in his office, and they have been dragging on quite awhile. You will notice that I have already paid for the labor.

2. I have hesitated to copy the OUTLINE IN SPELLING before I wrote to you again. There are seven pages as it stands now. I cannot reduce it unless I start rewriting it, and I am loathe to do that. Will that be alright? You can have it immediately if that is satisfactory, as it is ready to copy finally.

3. I got a couch for the verandah. You ignored my previous reference to the matter. I didn't think that it would be wise to put the good one outside, and the wisdom of that has been proven on several occasions. This one cost $11.50. I haven't paid for it, but if you won't I will before I leave.

4. I shall be around for a few weeks longer. Then I think that I will go home and have the operation on my throat. I will not be able to get away till mid-July though as I have just taken on some new work that will keep me that long. Tom is driving out West and I think that I will go with him and then I can recuperate at home. I plan to be back in the East by mid-August. May I have the awnings for the verandah? I practically live out there and it is horribly public for eating, sleeping, and what have you. Also I dislike having to get up in the middle of the night when it rains and move my bed. I gave you the cost once - seems to me that it was $16.00 inclusive of anything, and so on.

5. While I am away might I let the local rector use the house. He is a married man with one child, and having a rather hard time of it, I think. He is quite persona grata with the Indians. Apart from trying to get some kind of a holiday for him, I had rather that there was somebody in the house & my books, pictures and things are all here and I rather hate to leave them.

Sir:

Regarding the painting of Kettle Point School, I may say that the building needs painting badly, and an estimate of cost of material submitted last year was $35.00.

I do not think there would be any complaints about Mr. Dill and his brother doing the painting, when they are not being paid.

The condition of the building at present with some of the paint off entirely will mean a lot of work, and a thorough knowledge of painting, to assure a good job, but I trust the boys have taken this into consideration.

The $35.00 is for paint and oils only and does not include brushes and ladders etc.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, June 8, 1935.

Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 5th instant, giving an estimate of the cost of the materials required in painting the Kettle Point Indian Day School, I have to say that you may incur an expenditure, not exceeding the sum of $35.00, in the purchase of the paint, oil, brushes, etc. You should procure these materials from firms on the approved list.

It is understood that the work in painting the building will be carried out by the teacher and his brother, without expense to the Department.

When the materials have been purchased, you should obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, which you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward to the Department for payment.

The Department understands that the painting will be done during the coming summer holidays. We are not prepared to authorize the purchase of any ladders for the purpose. It is considered that arrangements could be made to borrow this equipment, if needed.

Your obedient servant,

T.A.K. MacInnes,

Dear Miss Lucas:

I have your letter regarding the piano which is at present in the Kettle Pt. School.

I borrowed this piano at Christmas from Grant Milligan as I have done annually since I have been here. It is used in preparation for the Christmas concert. My agreement with them is that I have it tuned upon the return.

This year when I was able to arrange for professional training in music for the School and their later entry in the County Musical Festival, some of the Indians asked me if I would like to keep the piano in the School if the band paid for it. I agreed, as it had become more or less necessary if we were to carry out the work in music.

More than that I know nothing about it, except that it was never called for and that we use it daily.

Dear Sir,

With reference to the matter of installing Hydro service in the Kettle Point School, the Indian Agent has informed me that sufficient funds are not available for this at the present time.

I realize that the quoted price for the wiring and installation of fixtures was a great deal and I have asked the Chambers Electric of Sarnia, the suggested electricians, for a quotation covering the minimum. They have quoted me a price of one hundred seventy dollars. This will allow for the required lights in the actual class-room and the teacher's residence. All outside outlets, cloakrooms, basement, attic and cupboard lights have been eliminated to secure this figure. The price will include six fixtures for the schoolroom at nine dollars each. The amount could be lowered by three or four dollars by putting all the classroom lights on one switch but I feel that this would be poor economy from the standpoint of the monthly bills for electricity as there will be numerous times when half the lights will answer the purpose of lighting there. Also included in the price will be one fixture for the kitchen and one for the hallway of the residence. The remainder I can supply myself for the time being.

I shall be grateful if you will give the matter your further consideration. I have arranged a course in visual aid which I am anxious to test this winter and have planned extensive night work with the older boys and girls and the parents. Lighting facilities would be a great help in all this work.

MEMORANDUM

Dr. McGill

Apr. 20, 1937

Re: Kettle Point School

Please note the letter I have received from Mr. Ross W. Gray, M.P., in regard to the installation of lighting and heating at the above school, and be good enough to let me have a draft reply.

W.J. Pratt
Secretary.

Enclosure Apr. 15.
Ottawa, April 27, 1937.

Dear Mr. Gray,-

I am in receipt of your letter of April 15th, with reference to placing new heating equipment in the Kettle Point Indian Day School and, also, installing electricity.

The estimate that has been received indicates that the total cost of the above work would be in the vicinity of $570.00. No provision has been made in our current year's appropriation for the funds for these improvements. I may add that the lighting and heating arrangements at the Kettle Point School at the present time compare favourably with other Indian day schools throughout the Dominion. I regret, therefore, that it will not be possible to consider any new arrangements regarding lighting and heating at the Kettle Point Indian Day School this year.

Yours sincerely,

Secretary.

Ross W. Gray, Esq., M.P.,
Chief Government Whip,
Sarnia, Ont.
MEMORANDUM:

The Deputy Minister.

I am in receipt of Mr. Pratt's memorandum of April 26th, enclosing letter received from Mr. Ross W. Gray, M. P., in regard to the installation of lighting and heating at the Kettle Point Indian Day School.

The estimated cost of the installation of a heating plant in this school is $275.00; the cost of wiring and fixtures, if arrangements were made with the Hydro Electric Commission to supply the electricity, would be $295.00. This means a total cost of $570.00 and no funds have been specifically provided in our appropriation this year for this work.

The Kettle Point Indian Day School is in good condition and, at present, is heated by stoves. The teacher's residence is lighted by lamps. Artificial light is only required at infrequent intervals in the classroom. The provision for lighting and heating at the Kettle Point School compares favourably with other Indian day schools throughout the Dominion. It is not considered necessary to make an exception at this day school by providing electric light and, as far as we are aware, the heating arrangements at present in effect keep the classroom comfortable. As pointed out above, no provision has been made for any heavy expenditure at this school during the present fiscal year and, in consideration of this fact, I enclose a draft reply to Mr. Gray.

Director.
Forest, Ont.,

I suddenly remembered that I had forgotten to tell you the name of the lad of whom I wrote last week. In case you haven't already heard it from the other correspondence, it is Donald Tait of Watford.

D.
Forest, Ont.,
August 10th, 1937.

Dear Phil,

One of the lads and I are doing some work around here this summer and I need some more material to finish it. Time is going very quickly and so I am writing directly to you to avoid time. I have just written to the Agent about another matter and have told him what I am doing.

I would like ten bags of cement. The woodshed has come off its foundations and there is going to be a collapse if I don't get it onto another one.

I would like a little lumber.
140 feet 2 by four
14 feet 4 by 4
140 feet 1 by 1
140 feet 1 by 2

If I buy the winter's coal now I will save $1.50 per ton so the dealer was telling me the other day. I use four tons. May I order it now?

Can you send me a copy of the letter to the agent if you authorize this so that I can get at it at once for there is only a couple of weeks left?

Thank you.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

I knew there was one other thing. I want to get about ten loads of earth and manure drawn up into the yard to work into the gardens. It is one dollar a load. Could it be arranged?
Ottawa, August 16, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I have, for acknowledgment, your letter of the 10th instant, addressed to Mr. Phelan.

Mr. Phelan is at present absent from the city and your communication has been passed on to me for consideration and reply.

I may state, by way of comment, that Mr. McGookin, Inspector of Indian Agencies for the province of Ontario, will visit your district early this week. At that time he will discuss with you and the Agent the request contained in your letter. Mr. McGookin will have power to authorize the purchase of supplies, if, in his judgment, the repairs are urgently needed.

Yours truly,

R. A. Heay,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

George Dill, Esq.,
Teacher,

Dear Sir:

During my last visit to Kettle Point School my attention was drawn to the condition of some of the doors, both in the school and in the residence. It looks to me as if green timber was used very extensively around the building, with the inevitable result the doors are leaving the frames and the casings are warping. This should be attended to before it goes too far.

I also have to make a report with reference to the toilets. I think they should be moved to the north-west corner of the school-yard. At present they are facing the kitchen door of the residence which is not very pleasant and also very embarrassing for Mrs. Howard and the children, to say nothing of the unsanitary condition.

Some painting is also needed around the buildings. I think the time to do these things is the spring of the year. If a building is worth building, it is worth keeping in repair.

Should you approve of these repairs, I will obtain estimates on the work and forward same to the Department.

DIRECTIONS

The Surface—Before painting, walls must be cleaned thoroughly, removing grease spots and dirt. Old paint, kalsomine and paper must be cleaned, and the loose paint or paper removed. Damaged surfaces should never be painted. Cracks in plaster must be filled with plaster, and knots in wood covered with shellac.

The Paint—Stir thoroughly from the bottom until the contents of the can are of uniform consistency. If too heavy, thin with turpentine only. If the color must be changed, tint Mellotone White with other colors by mixing in proper manner with each of the other tints or colors of Mellotone. It should be applied freely with a good wall brush.

Application—To secure best results on large surfaces and overcome brush marks, be sure to use a full stock brush 3½ to 4 inches wide. Mellotone should not be brushed out like a paint but should be flowed on freely and levelled off like an enamel.

First Coating—On common porous plaster walls, use a mixture of two parts Mellotone, using color chosen for finishing, and from two to three parts Sealcote, varying according to surface conditions. If the wall is very absorbent, apply first a coat of Sealcote, straight, then a coat of the Mellotone and Sealcote mixture. The latter process will need, in the majority of cases, only an additional final coat of Mellotone.

On hard, non-porous plaster walls, the best first coater is High Standard Liquid Paint because of its penetrating and binding properties. Use a color of High Standard corresponding to that of the Mellotone chosen for finishing. Thin with about one-half pint of turpentine to a gallon of High Standard Liquid Paint, and allow three days or longer for drying.

Burned areas, or wood should be given a coat of High Standard Liquid Paint of a color corresponding to that of the Mellotone chosen for finishing. Surfaces repeatedly finished with Flat Wall Paints should be re-sized when necessary before re-painting.

If burned spots from the plaster show through the sizing coat of Mellotone, apply another coat of size over the spots, and let it thoroughly dry before putting on the next coat. Allow twenty-four to thirty-six hours after sizing for thorough drying and hardening.

Glue size, gloss oil and similar cheap first coaters should not be used under Mellotone for the tenacity written up and give a good appearance to the finished work.

Finishing Coats—When the priming coat is uniformly dry, hard and glossy, apply the finishing coats of Mellotone allowing at least twenty-four to thirty-six hours between coats. While one coat may seem sufficient to give a solid color, two coats are strongly recommended. It is unreasonable to expect one thin coat of paint to withstand washing, cleaning and years of wear.

MELLOTONE

A Flat Wall Finish

Mellotone is a durable paint ready for use—not a calcimine or water finish. Its color effects are soft and beautiful, permanent, sanitary and washable.

Mellotone is equally good for walls, woodwork, steel ceilings, radiators, plaster, wood, burlap, canvas and board. It is easy to apply and covers 500 to 800 square feet per gallon, one coat depending upon the surface. Mellotone flat finish is intended for use in homes as well as public buildings, hospitals and institutions where refinement of decoration is desired. For complete directions see back of color card.

IMPORTANT

In selecting Mellotone colors it is important to know:

(a) that the greater the mass of color, the deeper the shade appears to be, also
(b) that the color effect from one wall on another greatly intensifies the color effect.

It is therefore necessary to make allowance for the influence of mass and reflection by reducing the color with White. For example, Rose Tint Mellotone matches the color in the case. When applied to a large surface however, it appears, for reasons mentioned above, much darker on the wall.

For best decorative results, we recommend the following colors be reduced in the proportion of one part of color to one part of White:

Rose Tint Blue Tint
Primrose Yellow Beryl Green
Oyster Gray Medium Blue Orchid

This is particularly necessary if the room is inclined to be dark. For large and very bright rooms, we recommend that the color in the case be reduced with 2 parts of color to one part of White.

MELLOTONE SUPER SEALER No. 642

Mellotone Super Sealer is an exceptionally efficient primer and sealer which is especially adapted for two coat work on new walls—or for special treatment on walls that are "green" or not thoroughly dried out.

Its chief characteristics are to be found in its damp proof qualities; in its alkali resisting properties; in its remarkable efficiency; in its ease of brushing and in its ability to seal and prime the surface in one coat.

New and damp walls can be primed with Mellotone Super Sealer with a measure of safety and satisfaction, heretofore unattainable with any type of primer. In many cases the "third" coat necessary in finishing new work can be eliminated through the use of Super Sealer—one coat of which serves both as sealer and primer coat.

Super Sealer is made in White only—but may be tinted with any color except White at time of the finishing coat. It covers 400 to 650 square feet one coat to the gallon and in respect to general performance, service and economy is one of the outstanding developments in moisture proof; alkali resistant; sealer primers.

Minute of Kettle & Stony Point Council, July 21, 1938

Moved by Caleb Shawkense, seconded by Dan Bressette, that we ask the Department to drill a well at the Kettle Point Indian Day School at an estimated cost of $175.00.

Dear Sir:

With reference to the enclosed Minute of the Regular Monthly Council of the Kettle & Stony Point Band held July 21, 1938, Mr. Howard, teacher of the Kettle Point Day School, reported the well dry and in bad condition generally.

Looking back over 1936 records, I find authority was given on July 15th to have this well cleaned out and put in shape. Vouchers show Ernest Bressette was paid $6.40 on July 30th.

I am told there is more or less trouble with this well and it seems to me the only satisfactory way to correct this condition would be to drill a new well. However, I would also advise that the conditions in this particular locality might make it necessary to go down 100 feet before striking rock and there is, of course, always the chance of a dry hole. This information I received at an interview with Mr. Heal, driller, Petrolia.

It is quite evident something should be done with this well. To clean it out again would only mean boosting it perhaps for a few months, then again the same trouble. Therefore, I would recommend the approval of $175.00 for the purpose of drilling a new well. This amount will take care of the drilling and new casing for 100 feet.

Your obedient servant,

August 5th, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant with reference to the well at Kettle Point day school.

It is inferred from the first paragraph of your letter that the teacher at the Kettle Point school, Mr. Howard, reported the condition of the well to the Council. If so, he should not have followed such procedure. All expenditure in connection with Indian education is paid from appropriation and not from Band Funds. Consequently, if there is any matter at an Indian School that requires attention, the teacher should report it to you.

You will remember last May you were advised regarding the amount specifically provided in the appropriation for repairs and improvements on the three schools in the Sarnia Agency. In replying, you made no mention that it might be necessary to drill a new well at Kettle Point. Under these circumstances, it is practically impossible to provide funds this year for a new well.

Please visit Kettle Point as soon as you can conveniently do so, with a view to ascertaining if the present well could not be cleaned or possibly a few additional lengths of pipe would result in water being secured.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 2nd instant Mr. Phelan did not make any definite promise to Mr. Howard that this Branch would allow payment for the cabinet he built in the bedroom of the teacher's residence at Kettle Point. SARNIA, Ontario  
August 17, 1939

Dear Sir:

On March 11, 1939, voucher # 84 was submitted in favour of Geo. Coultis & Sons, Thedford, Ontario, for the amount of $41.67 for material supplied the Kettle Point Indian Day School, for the building of a screened porch.

I would refer you to Mr. Phelan's visit in 1938 to this Agency, when I showed him the screened porch in question. This I understand was built during the time of Mr. Geo. Dill's residence as teacher at this school; Mr. Dill did purchase this material without authority, thus making Mr. Coultis the loser.

However, as the porch still stands today as a part of the residence, I do not think (nor did Mr. Phelan when I pointed it out to him) that Mr. Coultis should lose this account. Mr. Coultis reports to me that he has not received payment nor any reason as to why payment was not made. I think it only just, in view of the fact that all the material in question is still in use, that he should receive payment.

Under the circumstances I would recommend payment of this account. If such is not approved would you kindly advise this office.

Your obedient servant,

Geo. W. Down

Dear Sir:

The officials inform me that they have made a diligent search of the records here and cannot discover on file at the Department the voucher to which you refer. If you will send forward to the Department a voucher for the amount quoted above, together with full particulars relating thereto, your request will be very carefully and very sympathetically reviewed.

Yours truly,

MONTHLY COUNCIL MEETING
KETTLE & STONY POINT RESERVES

THE regular Monthly Council Meeting was held in the Council Chamber, Thursday, December 12, 1940.

RESOLUTION NO. 3

Moved by Wellington Elijah, seconded by Bruce Milliken that we grant $3.00 School Treat for Kettle Point School and $2.00 for Stony Point School.

Carried.

With reference to Resolution No. 3, it has been an annual grant for the children's Christmas treats. I would recommend the request be approved and an advance cheque forwarded to this office to the amount of $5.00.

Geo. W. Down,
Indian Agent.

OTTAWA, Canada.
Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 13th instant the Department is not allowing any grant from the vote for Indian education in order to provide Christmas treats at Indian day schools this year. As our funds have been reduced this action is necessary. Please understand that no grant is being made to any Indian school in Canada for this purpose.

It is considered that the teacher should be able to arrange a concert before Christmas and either charge a small admission fee or take up a collection. By so doing sufficient funds should be raised to provide a Christmas treat for the pupils attending the school. In addition it should have a tendency to make the Indian parents realize that they have some obligations with regard to the education of their children.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. Geo. W. Down,
Indian Agent,
Sarnia, Ont.

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. McGill

I beg to submit the following report covering my visit to the Sarnia Agency on May 4th, 5th and 6th.

WETTLE POINT INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

Mr. Howard was interviewed - he seems to be working under difficulties, some pupils were outside reading, others sitting on the school steps studying, the remainder inside. Questioned, regarding the matter he complained of having only twenty-four complete desks with forty-one pupils enrolled. Attendance today was thirty-two - seating accommodation is lacking and I would recommend the purchase of sufficient desks to accommodate at least all pupils other than the youngest class. Outbuildings fairly clean.

W.S. Arneil,

SARNIA, Ontario,
June 26, 1942.

Dear Sir:

On a recent visit to Kettle Point Indian Day School, I found that some minor repairs will be necessary to the building during the summer months.

Screens on the windows will have to be replaced as they have rusted and are not serving any useful purpose in their present condition. The steps on the porch on both sides of the school have loose boards which will have to be replaced and other repair work done to the railings on the porches. The roof on the school is in need of some shingles.

Mr. Howard, the teacher of this school, will be able to do the repair work as he had done in the past. He does this work satisfactorily and at less expense than if a carpenter were employed.

The total cost of material and labour is estimated to be $12.00. I would recommend that the Department authorize this expenditure. Accounts would be submitted to the Department for payment and no accountable advance Cheque will be necessary.

Your obedient servant,

M. W. McCracken,
INDIAN AGENT.

In Departmental letter 29-2-1 of May 21, 1943, I was instructed to advise Mr. Howard, Teacher of Kettle Point Indian Day School, that his services would not be required as from June 30, 1943. I informed Mr. Howard of the Departmental decision.

During our discussion, Mr. Howard mentioned that he had erected a wardrobe in one of the upstairs bedrooms in 1938. This structure is seven feet long and six feet high and is too large to be removed from the residence. Mr. Howard states that he paid for this wardrobe himself at a cost of $26.90. He is of the opinion that he should be reimbursed for this expenditure as it is a necessity in the residence. In this connection, I would beg to refer you to Departmental letter 29-2-5 of November 5, 1938 in which it was stated that payment could not be considered in view of the fact that Mr. Howard did not secure any authority for the erection of the cabinet. Mr. Howard maintains that Mr. Phelan authorized this expenditure in the presence of former Inspector McGookin.

I informed Mr. Howard that I would write to the Department to ascertain if payment for the cabinet would be allowed. It appears as though the ruling given in Departmental letter of November 5, 1938 was justified and cannot be altered but Mr. Howard demanded reconsideration. A reply regarding this matter would be greatly appreciated.

M. W. McCracken

M. W. McCracken,

However, the Department is prepared to allow Mr. Howard an amount of $15.00 for this wardrobe, provided he can produce receipted accounts showing that the cost of the material used either equalled or exceeded this amount. Mr. M.W. McCracken, Indian Agent, Sarnia, Ont.

When Inspector Arnell and Mr. Phelan visited Kettle Point on May 25 it was understood that you would forward a requisition for the material required to erect the addition to the Kettle Point School. I have not yet received this and it would be appreciated if you would forward it at the earliest possible date, in order that the materials may be secured before the end of the month, at which time the Indian carpenter stated he could commence work on the addition.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa,
May 27, 1944.

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY

Re: Kettle Point Day School

Accompanied by Inspector Arneil, I visited the Kettle Point School on Tuesday, May 23. You will remember that two proposals were discussed some time ago; namely, (1) an addition to the Kettle Point School; (2) erection of a new school at some other point on the reserve.

At the present time there are 57 children of school age registered at the Kettle Point School and 3 of these will probably not return for the academic year 1944-45, but there will be 6 younger children attending for the first time. This makes a probable enrolment for the coming academic year of 60. Of course, if any of the children from Kettle Point now attending the Mount Elgin Residential School were discharged and arrangements made to have them attend the day school on the reserve, this number would be increased.

We first checked very carefully the location of all the children of school age on the reserve and it was found that 4 children live between 2½ and 3½ miles from the Kettle Point Day School; 7 of the children live between 1 and 2 miles from the school; the remainder live within 1 mile of the school, many of them within only ¼ or ½ mile.

In view of the above, Mr. Arneil, Indian Agent McCracken and myself consider that our best course of action is to add another room to the present Kettle Point School. This suggestion offers the further advantage that living accommodations for the two teachers are available in the living quarters at the Kettle Point School.

The Indian Agent had already located an Indian who resides very close to the Kettle Point School. This man is a competent carpenter and has erected several buildings on the reserve in a very satisfactory manner. We brought him to the school during the course of the afternoon and discussed the location of a possible addition. It is felt that an addition 24' x 24' on a cement base would be satisfactory. The Indian carpenter estimated the cost of the material at $900 and the cost of the labour at approximately $800. He, himself, expected to receive 75¢ an hour as foreman-carpenter and he stated that he could engage other labour required on the reserve at the rate of 50¢ an hour. He further stated that he could erect the addition within a five-week period starting July 1.
As there is no basement under the Kettle Point School it was not considered advisable to put a basement under the new addition. By using the two rooms alternately arrangements could be made for teaching domestic science to the girls and manual training to the boys.

I instructed Mr. McCracken to forward, for our consideration, a list of the materials required at the earliest possible date.

Mr. Arneil, the Indian Agent and myself are satisfied that this addition will adequately meet the needs of the school population at Kettle Point and, as you will note from the above, the new classroom can be erected at a reasonable cost.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

During May attendance at the Kettle Point school was very low due to measles and mumps which existed in practically every home. The attendance at St Clair school was fair. Inspector Arneil and Mr. P. More accommodation for school children at Kettle Point is quite necessary and a new classroom is to be built this summer if present plans materialize. We shall require two teachers at Kettle Point as Miss Fairservice, presently teaching, has resigned with effect from June 30th, 1944. I regret that I was visiting the Kettle Point Reserve and not available when Mr. Phelan phoned. Apparently the message was to the effect that George Coults & Son, lumber dealers at Thedford did not wish to quote and that Mr. Phelan wished me to obtain quotations on materials from R. Prout & Son at Forest and W. J. Travis & Son at Wyoming.

On July 7, I forwarded the enclosed list of materials to the dealers at Forest and Wyoming and asked them to let me have quotations at the earliest possible date. R. Prout & Son do not wish to quote on the materials and a letter verifying this is enclosed from Mr. Prout. After some delay I received a quotation from Mr. Travis although it is in a lump sum rather than quotations on individual items. Mr. Travis also advises that some substitutes will have to be made and that it is doubtful if he can supply hardwood flooring. He suggests that birch flooring be used as a substitute. I am enclosing the letter and quotation as received from the Travis Co.

I suggest that the Department approve of purchasing materials from W. J. Travis & Son at Wyoming.

When this work is in progress, various additional miscellaneous material will likely be needed and I suggest that I be authorized to purchase same locally when and as required. I also suggest that an advance cheque for $500.00 be forwarded to this office.

(Over)
to pay for labour. The above amount will not cover all labour costs and a further advance will be requested when first $500.00 has been spent. The Indian who is to be placed in charge of this work states that he can start as soon as the materials are delivered.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources,

Re: Erection of Additional Classroom
Kettle Point Indian Day School.

Please be advised that work on the above mentioned building was commenced on July 27th, 1944. Since that date good progress has been made. The foundation has been completed and a fair amount of the framework has been erected. The Travis firm in Wyoming who are supplying most of the materials advise that some items such as flooring are difficult to obtain. They have promised to make every effort to procure the materials which we need as soon as possible.

Up to the present time no blackboards for the new building have been ordered. I called various firms in Samia but they do not handle school blackboard material and I was wondering if the blackboards required for the new school could be obtained through the Department. The new classroom will be 24' long and 24' wide. I suggest that slate blackboards be placed across the front of the room and along one side. If the blackboards were 3' 6" wide we would need approximately 168 square feet. I suggest that the Department endeavour to procure blackboard material of some kind at an early date to avoid inconvenience and delay in opening the school.

(over).....
A box stove will also be needed in the new classroom. One which would meet our requirements would cost in the neighbourhood of $30.00. A local firm in Forest could order the stove for us if this meets with Departmental approval. Please advise if I am authorized to purchase the stove which would be about 32" long and 15" wide. I might add that the stove which was in the former Stony Point school was practically useless as the fire box was cracked in several places.

M. W. McCracken

On a recent visit to Kettle Point Indian Day School I inspected the well and found that the covering for the top is dangerous. A portion of the covering is cement and the balance is wood. The wooden part has rotted and portions of the cement have broken away leaving a hole into which small children might fall. The well is almost dry at the present time and it is dirty. I have already instructed an Indian to clean it as the water in the well cannot be used in its present condition. I suggest that a new top, built entirely of cement, be placed on the well at an estimated cost of $25.00 for material and labour. Would you kindly advise if an expenditure along the above lines will be approved and if so please forward an accountable Advance Cheque for $25.00 so that I may pay the Indian who performs the labour.

October 4, 1944.

I visited the new classroom at Kettle Point Indian Day School last week and found that more equipment is necessary. The funds which were sent to cover labour were not sufficient to complete all phases of the work. The following is a list of work which is still required to place the classroom in good condition:

- 30 Hooks for children's coats
- 2 Shelves for lunches
- 1 Coal bin
- Applying second coat of paint to the new building
- Setting up new stove and pipes
- Installing blackboards
- Levelling school grounds adjacent to the new building for drainage purposes
- Insulating three rooms
- Erection of shelving for teachers books
- Providing three storm doors
- 5 Window blinds

At the present time the blackboard which is being ordered through the Government Stationery Office has not arrived. This is urgently needed and it would be greatly appreciated if steps could be taken to have it forwarded without further delay.

In connection with the purchase of the stove authorized in your letter 29-2-5 of August 21, I would advise that box stoves to burn wood are not available. During the past few days the weather has been cold and the teacher needed some heat in the room. I purchased a Quebec Heater which was available and it will use coal instead of wood. I had to engage an Indian to set up the stove and he has not yet been paid for this labour. A storage for coal is required.

..............
The total cost of materials and labour in attending to the above requirements will be approximately $125.00. $85.00 would be for labour and $40.00 would cover the materials. If funds are available I suggest that a further accountable advance cheque of $85.00 for labour be forwarded. The materials could be purchased locally and submitted to the Department for payment.

All of the above work is quite necessary and I recommend that expenditures involved be approved.

M. W. McCracken,

MWM:FM

Sarnia, October 14, 1944.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

The two toilets at Kettle Point Indian Day School are in need of cleaning. I do not believe they have been cleaned for at least four years. I have found an Indian who will do the work. It has been customary to move each building and dig new holes four feet deep for the containers. If this were done it is expected that the toilets would not need cleaning again for at least two years. I recommend that the Department approve of this expenditure. A voucher could be submitted for payment when the work has been completed. An early reply regarding this will be appreciated.

Sarnia, November 10, 1944.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

I regret to inform that the two outhouses at Kettle Point Indian Day School were damaged quite extensively on Hallowe'en. The buildings were upset which resulted in sills, floors and side boards being broken. This damage will have to be repaired immediately and I have already instructed an Indian carpenter to perform the necessary work. As a result of the buildings being upset, very unsanitary conditions prevail at the present time. I could not persuade any Indian to work in these conditions unless one of the buildings is moved to a new location. The total cost of moving one outhouse and repairing both will be $12.00. The moving of the one building was more or less necessary as the two outhouses are too close thus causing confusion between boys and girls. I recommend that the Department approve of an expenditure of $12.00 to move and repair the toilets. When the work has been completed I shall submit a voucher to pay the Indian.

Those responsible for upsetting the buildings have not been apprehended. Presumably it was a group of rowdy Indian youths who take delight in damaging property. I have instructed the Indian Constable on the Reserve to investigate but it is doubtful if responsibility for the damage can definitely be placed on any one party.

M. W. McCracken,
INDIAN AGENT.
Ottawa,
November 13, 1944.

Mr. M.W. McCracken, Indian Agent, Sarnia, Ont.

With reference to your letter of the 10th instant, the Department approves the expenditure of $12 for moving and repairing the toilets at the Kettle Point School.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Enclosed please find voucher No. 140 amounting to $5.00 in favour of Telford Adams in payment for a second hand stove.

The church owned by the Band on the Sarnia Reserve has been dismantled. The lumber which was salvaged will be used to erect a new church. Some of the material which was salvaged could not be used and the Band appointed a committee to dispose of the articles and materials which would not be utilized. Telford Adams is the treasurer of this committee.

The committee decided to sell the old stove which was in the church. Upon examination I found that the stove was in fair condition and would be suitable for use in the Senior room of the Kettle Point Indian Day School. The stove which was in this class room was broken and had to be discarded. I decided to purchase the second hand stove from the church committee and have already taken it to Kettle Point. I took this action to save the expense of purchasing a new stove and consider that the one now obtained will serve the required purpose.

It is recommended that the Department approve of this expenditure and a check in favour of Telford Adams, treasurer of the church committee should be forwarded for delivery to him.

November 2, 1945.

I visited Kettle Point Indian Day School on November 1st and regret to report that the boys' outhouse was upset and damaged by Halloween pranksters on October 31st. The parties responsible for the damage have not been determined at the present time, but the matter is still being investigated by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. I have already instructed an Indian to reset and repair the building at an estimated cost of $10.00 for labour.

In addition to the above I suggest that funds be made available to make some minor alterations in the Junior class room. This room is quite crowded at the present time and more seating accommodation would result if a partition at the back of the room were removed. The material in this partition could be used for making a cupboard and shelves for school supplies. This should be done in the near future as storage space for supplies has been requested by the teacher. Coat hangers will have to be removed from the present partition and installed on the walls.

Screen doors and window screens should also be taken off and replaced by storm sash.

It is estimated that $25.00 will be required to perform all of the above mentioned work and I recommend that an accountable advance cheque be forwarded for this sum at an early date so that I may pay the Indian who is doing the labour.

In your letter 29-2-1 (WT 1) of March 31st you informed me that Miss Eileen I. Gibson had been engaged as Sr. teacher at Kettle Point Indian Day School with duties to commence on May 3rd. As you are aware this classroom has not been in operation since June, 1946 and some repairs are required to put it in satisfactory condition for the new teacher. New steps on the main entrance are necessary as they were completely destroyed by a rowdy group of Indian boys who congregated at the school at night. The pump in the well is not working and I suspect that it needs new leathers. About eighteen window panes have been broken by Indian children with sling shots. Mrs. Clemens, the teacher in the Jr. room, also requests that a small storage for books be provided.

I have already instructed an Indian named Robert George to attend to these repairs at an estimated cost of $30.00 for material and labour. Would you please forward an accountable advance cheque for this amount to enable me to pay George when he finishes the work. Enclosed please find voucher #188 amounting to $8.60 in favour of Robert George, c/o Indian Agent, Sarnia, Ontario for labour performed and materials supplied in repairing inside toilet for teachers at Kettle Point School.

Re: Hydro - Kettle Point School & Teachers' Residence.

You are aware that hydro has not been made available on Kettle Point Reserve due to scarcity of materials and insufficient number of Indian applicants for electrical service. Some Kettle Point Indians have applied and their applications have already been approved but to date the number of users per mile is less than the minimum required by the Hydro-Electric Power Commission to justify erection of a new line. The local Hydro official at Forest states that it is very unlikely that a new line could be built on Kettle Point Reserve in 1948 even if a sufficient number of Indian applicants were procured as many white applicants have filed applications and are on the waiting list.

There is little chance of hydro being available for Kettle Point School and Teachers' Residence this year unless priority over adjacent white localities is secured. If we fail to obtain hydro for the school and residence it may be quite difficult to get teachers next September.

There is an existing line running along the easterly boundary of the Reserve. To get hydro in the school only six-tenths of a mile of new line would be required. Possibly the Education Division could arrange some priority with the Hydro-Electric Power Commission to erect this length of line in the near future. Then the school and teachers' residence could be wired this summer so that hydro would be installed before September 1st.

The local manager of the Hydro-Electric Power Commission in Forest is quite willing to erect such a line if we obtain

In this connection I have prepared a rough sketch of the Kettle Point Reserve. Our Indian Council Hall and United Church, which are both situated in the south-easterly extremity of the Reserve, secure electric power from the line marked in green. There are no white people living adjacent to the southerly limits of the Reserve which explains why a line has not been erected along that boundary.

The red line indicates the new line (about 6/10 of a mile) which would have to be erected to supply hydro as far west as the school. A few Indians living on lots between the Council Hall and the school may make application for hydro later on but at the moment they do not appear very enthusiastic which is no doubt due to lack of funds for wiring.

The Kettle Point Council have authorized electric service on Kettle Point Reserve and in this connection I beg to refer to Departmental letter 37029-2 of June 23rd, 1947 and my reply of July 12th, 1947.

As you probably know, we are making a very strenuous effort this year to catch up on our back-log of applicants for rural extension. This includes the construction of at least 3400 miles of line and the connection of approximately 35,000 customers. Despite all this activity, we do not anticipate catching up completely with the back-log, which will extend into 1949. In order to be as fair as possible with all our rural applicants, we have had to put each rural operating area on a quota basis. As advised you in my telephone conversation, Mr. Leslie Claus has accepted the position of welfare teacher at the above Indian Day School, effective August 1, 1948, for a trial period of one year.

I was very frank with Mr. Claus in discussing the situation both at the school and on the reserve. I understand that you also told him the situation as it existed at present and also some of the background as to why a strong teacher will be required. I would ask that arrangements be made to have the following repair work done during the month of August, under Mr. Claus' supervision:

(1) Erection of two new toilets. (Mr. Claus has been given the blueprints for these toilets and will work out the bill of materials required to construct them. I have suggested that Insul Brick be used for the exterior finish).

(2) The erection of a new wood-shed. (Mr. Claus will also work out a bill of materials for this wood-shed and will advise you also as to the amount of materials which we will have to order through the Purchasing Agent for Items 1 and 2.
(3) Purchase of Cistern. (I would ask that you ascertain the type of cistern required at the school and if it can be purchased locally for less than $50.00, that you do so. If the cost is more than $50.00, please submit a requisition covering same for action by the Purchasing Agent.

(4) Interior painting. (I am today placing a requisition with the Departmental Purchasing Agent for the following paint supplies:

2 gallons light green Kem-tone or similar plaster paint.
2 " white Kem-tone or similar plaster paint.
1 " light green interior enamel
1 Kalsomine brush
1 2" paint brush.
2 Quarts Turpentine.

I would ask that you extend every cooperation to Mr. Claus in this undertaking. While Mr. Claus will assume responsibility for the repairs to be carried out at the school during the month of August, I would ask that you do everything possible to see that the school is put into fit condition by the 7th of September. Please let me know also concerning the cost of placing a telephone in the school.

Bernard E. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

P.S. - I would emphasize that we are only guessing at quantities of paint required but wish to ensure that some paint at least is on hand when Mr. Claus arrives. You can submit a further requisition after discussing with him the paint requirements for the school and teacherage.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter
29-2-5 of August 6th with reference to procuring prices
of materials required for erection of a woodshed as well
as two new toilets at Kettle Point Indian Day School.

Enclosed please find quotations from R. Prout & Son, Forest, Ontario and George Coultis & Son, Thedford, Ontario covering materials as listed on the requisition which you returned. The cost of same is much greater than I expected.

In my opinion the building of a new woodshed and garage is not essential this year. The present structure could be put in a reasonable state of repair at a total cost of possibly $100.00. I recommend that the plans for erection of a new garage and woodshed be cancelled and authority be granted to repair the existing building.

Two new toilets are urgently required. I suggest that only materials which will be necessary for the toilets be ordered as per the enclosed bill which was submitted by Mr. Claus. The two toilets at Kettle Point School are in very bad condition at the present time. In fact one was upset and broken some time ago. As we intended to build new toilets I did not repair either of the old ones. School is commencing next Tuesday and for this reason I recommend that authority be granted for local purchase of the materials required so that the erection of these outbuildings may be commenced immediately.

M. W. McCracken,
Superintendent, Sarnia Indian Agency.
